TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Defence. In view of the announcement this morning by the honourable member for Newcastle and chairman of the Caucus sub-committee on defence manufacturing, and the release in London this week of Australian eyes only information in Jane's Defence Weekly relating to the vital specifications of the new submarine project, can the Minister assure the House of the absolute sanctity of the project definition study and the tendering process in order that the Australian public can be satisfied on the basis of the new submarine contract being let?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the right honourable gentleman for his question. The release of the document related to comments by the honour-able member for Newcastle is not new. I understand that that document was circulating around the Cabinet before the Cabinet decision. Matters contained in it raised questions that were amply covered by Cabinet consideration. I understand too that it was released some weeks ago and run in the Australian Financial Review, so I do not know what has provoked the Canberra Times to pick it up three weeks later. All of the matters raised in it were amply covered in Cabinet consideration. In many areas the detail of it is based on incorrect assumptions about judgments that the Royal Australian Navy and others were making in the evaluation process or is slightly distorted-but distorted in important ways.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no reason to be concerned about any information released from that or any information which has been released in the course of the submarine project evaluation. Naturally enough, we would prefer that that had not happened, as I have indicated in this House on a number of occasions. But it is virtually unavoidable in a contest such as this with a project of close to $4 billion at stake and where the contenders for that project will see their situation materially advanced or damaged by a decision taken by an intelligent buyer such as the Royal Australian Navy. We have to live with that.

It is not often that we have projects of that size. They may come along every 5, 6 or 10 years. When we do have such projects, as happened in the case of the purchase of the F18 aircraft under the previous Government, that type of detail of capability does get discussed-again, in ways that we would probably prefer did not happen. The fact is that from this pro-ject we will have the best conventional submarine in the Western world when its construction is completed. That judgment is based on very sound analysis by the Navy. We are in the position where we could happily at any time sign a contract to that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Health inform the House as to the protection offered to the Australian family by the Medicare program in light of recent claims about the dismantling of Medicare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the question from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, it gives me very great pleasure to tell the House of the very real advantages that accrue to the Australian population from the Medicare program. The first of those is the fact that it is universal, that it covers every Australian, providing him or her with basic medical and hospital care. I would remind the House that only four years ago that was not so; some two million Australians were without health cover. It is true that the Opposition has said that it will maintain the universality of the program, but I must point out that Mr Fraser said exactly the same in 1975 and within seven years there were two million people without cover.

ANSWER.PARA: The second great advantage of the Medicare program is that it provides access to our public hospitals without means tests, without the need to have poor cards, without the need for a person to prove that he or she is a charitable case. In fact, despite what is said by many members of the Opposition, the public hospital system in this country treats some 60,000 new patients on average every week. But of course the Opposition says that people will have to present cards to entitle them to those kinds of free services in our public hospital system and the rest of the population will have to pay much more in health contribution rates in order to cover that.

The third and most important achievement of the Medicare program is that it is basically funded by payment according to people's means; that is, people pay the Medicare levy according to their income. There are generous threshold provisions which protect low income families, and they will be maintained under this Government. The remaining members of the population pay a levy according to their means. We have already been told that that fair system is to be undermined. I notice that Senator Michael Baume has already confessed that five million Australians will be worse off under the Opposition's scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—He has said that five million people may be worse off under the Opposition's plan, and that is an underestimate. The kinds of levels under which the Liberal scheme will work will mean that unless a family is earning something like $1,250 a week--

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point or order. The Minister has been asked a question about government policies and the effect that they will have. He should not, in my submission, in answer to that question, seek to tell the public at large his interpretation of the policies of the Opposition and, Madam Speaker, I respectfully suggest that you should tell him to be relevant to the question and to discontinue his--
—Order! The honourable member is now going against what the Chair has said to him. I will make the decisions, not him. I find the Minister in order, and he may continue.

—It is evident from the way the Opposition treats these five million people-and I heard the interjection that they all vote Labor-that that is the kind of attitude it takes to the less well off in the community who will be handicapped by the kinds of proposals that it is making. As I pointed out, under these vague Liberal proposals, and they are admittedly vague, a family now with basic private insurance will need an income of $1,250 a week to be better off, and if the Opposition gets rid of all its savings, with a tax rebate that family will need $700 a week to be better off--
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point or order.
—Order! Is the honourable member for North Sydney again raising a point of order under standing order 145?
—That is so, under relevance, Madam Speaker, and I ask you to request the speaker to be relevant.
—I tell the honourable member that I have ruled the Minister in order, and that is the honourable member's second point of order after the Chair's ruling. I call the Minister.

—I confess that the proposals of members of the Opposition are vague. They have had four years to produce a health scheme and they have failed to do so. All they are prepared to do is simply to undermine a scheme which provides universal cover, open access to our hospital systems and fair and income-related levy payment.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In view of the Government's decision not to proceed with its Industrial Relations Bill until the next session of Parliament, can the Minister advise the House whether the Government is able to take any action in the interim to counteract the draconian Queensland industrial relations legislation? If so, what action can be taken and how quickly can it be instituted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to inform the honourable member for Capricornia that the Government is able to take alternative action, and it will do so within the next couple of weeks. I remind the House that the Queensland legislation to which the honourable member referred as draconian is, indeed, draconian. It provides for the virtual outlawing of industrial action in many Queensland industries, making industrial action in those industries, in effect, a criminal offence; it contains outrageous evidentiary and notice requirements; it is in breach of up to half a dozen international treaties to which Australia is a signatory; it seeks to apply not just to State registered unions but also to federally registered unions operating under Federal awards and it is additional to remedies which are available under the Federal law, including the Trade Practices Act and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It qualifies for the term `draconian'. The Government, in its Industrial Relations Bill, sought to override the Queensland legislation by providing that Federal law formed a code which excluded remedies under State legislation. When we deferred debate on the Bill to undertake further consultation with employer organisations and unions, we made it clear that the Government did not resile in any way from the need for the Bill to contain a code to exclude State legislation. Nevertheless, the fact remains that there will be necessarily an interregnum of a few months before that Bill can be passed by this Parliament. The Government has therefore considered what other action it could take to ensure that Queensland workers are protected and that the Queensland legislation does not become the focus of disruptive and damaging protest action.

ANSWER.PARA: Accordingly, today, with my ministerial colleague, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, I am announcing that the Commonwealth Government will initiate a High Court of Australia constitutional challenge to the Queensland Industrial (Commercial Practices) Act 1984-87. The proceedings will be commenced as soon as possible-within the next two or three weeks-seeking a declaration by the High Court that the Queensland Act is constitutionally invalid to the extent of its inconsistency with the relevant provisions of existing Commonwealth legislation, including the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904.

Madam Speaker, I am sure that all those who are concerned to minimise the level of industrial disputation in this country and who are concerned with fairness and equity will applaud that decision to take this constitutional challenge to override the Queensland legislation. But, of course in doing so they should recognise that the Federal Opposition has come out totally in favour of that legislation. The Leader of the Opposition, when asked on Brisbane radio a week or so ago whether he supported that legislation, said yes, he supported it. So, the Federal Opposition-at least, the Liberal Party part of it and presumably the National Party as well-supports this legislation, which is in breach of at least half a dozen international treaties to which Australia is a signatory and which applied right through the period for which they were in office under the Fraser Government. So they have no standards in this matter. They simply seek to support anything that will provoke industrial action, hoping that it will benefit their political position in this country. They will be deprived of that because I am quite sure that, as a result of the action taken by the Government, there will not be any damaging protest action by unions in relation to the Queensland legislation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: CanMr GRIFFITHS-Can the Treasurer inform the House of ways in which $3,000m can be cut from Commonwealth outlays, and, having regard to today's theme of the Opposition, with specific reference to the health system?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. The latter part of the question, in my submission, is clearly out of order.
—On the point of order, Madam Speaker--
—Order! I did not hear the first point of order.
—The question concluded with a reference, that was hard to hear, having regard to Opposition statements. That part of the question, in my submission, is out of order.
—Order! That part of the question is out of order.

—On the point of order, Madam Speaker: The previous question was directed to the Prime Minister, on two attempts by the Opposition Leader and one of his shadow spokesmen. It was about remarks by a person and was totally outside the Prime Minister's portfolio responsibilities. If the Opposition wishes to put questions that are blatantly out of order, the Government will not be responding to the kinds of intonations by the honourable member about answers being in or out of order.

—The previous question has nothing to do with the question before the Chair. The Treasurer is out of order. The second part of the question of the honourable member for Maribyrnong is out of order. I ask him to repeat the first part of his question.

—The substantive part of the question, of course, was as follows: Can the Treasurer inform the House of the ways in which $3,000m could be cut from Commonwealth outlays with specific reference to the health system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not possible to cut $3 billion out of the health system without smashing it. The fact is that any proposal to transfer $1.3 billion of Medicare medical benefits to health funds will reflect in the health fund rate, and any proposal to transfer $1.7 billion in Commonwealth payments to the State health system, to total $3 billion, must reflect in payments for health. As I indicated in the House yesterday, such a proposal would mean that someone now on an income of about $20,000 and paying $5 a week under the levy system for his health protection would pay about $27 a week under such a proposal. If levy payers are forced out of the system, the Commonwealth loses its Medicare levy receipts to about the same tune-$1.6 billion. So $1.7 billion savings, so called, in payments by the Commonwealth to the States would offset $1.6 billion of losses in Commonwealth levy payments.

ANSWER.PARA: That means that people with families, taxpayers with families and with children, and people in the low and middle income areas would be driven to about an extra $20 a week for health cover. It would mean, as the Opposition Leader said yesterday in commenting about such a proposal, that out-patient care in public hospitals would no longer be free. If some child had his leg broken at sport or received an injury to his eye or something else, he would be denied outpatient services in the hospital system. A person who had an accident at work would have to immediately pay to procure any services from the hospital and would lose out-patient support at that hospital. Such is the basis of the Opposition's tax policy. After all this time what we have come down to is a con trick and mirrors operation of a supposed $3 billion saving from the health system which would only transfer tax cuts to high income earners by lifting the health insurance payments of low and middle income earners by about $20 a week. But someone cynically remarked from the Opposition benches when the Minister for Health was speaking: `That will come from your voters anyway'. In other words, the cynical view from the honourable member for Wannon is that if people happen to be on low or middle incomes they can pay $20 a week because it does not matter. He says: `They do not vote for the coalition parties anyway. We will procure a 35 per cent tax rate for the people we truly represent, that is the people in the wealthy suburbs of the cities, and we will do it at the expense of the poor, the people with families and the people with low incomes'.

One would not mind if the Opposition said what it was doing. The Leader of the Opposition said that within 10 days he would bring his tax policy down. The truth is that the Opposition is still cobbling it together. It still does not have a tax policy. Last week the Leader of the Opposition said $3 billion would be cut from health; yesterday it was to be $2 billion; last night the shadow Minister for Health, Senator Michael Baume, was back to $3 billion. There is all this stress. The Leader of the Opposition takes the view that this cynical game with the Press Gallery and with the public, about ripping money off the health system to pay for a supposed tax policy that he has not been able to cobble together in the 18 months or two years that he has been the Leader of the Opposition, is a charade which should continue without the Opposition saying with any specificity where the money will be coming from for the irresponsible grab bag of election promises which the Opposition is putting.

I conclude on this point: It is impossible to take $3 billion from the Medicare system without forcing low and middle income families into an extra $20 a week for health cover. That will be way beyond any tax promise that even the Leader of the Opposition may irresponsibly make in the course of an election campaign. There are no savings to the Budget. It is a Budget deficit neutral proposition, and with a Budget deficit neutral proposition all that would happen is that the Budget deficit would be blown out, interest rates would rise and we would find those same people paying more for health cover, paying more in interest rates across the country as the financial market tightens up Australia in the face of such a policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industry advise the House on the implications for farmers and country Australia in general of a flat tax and reduced fuel taxes paid for by the abolition of Medicare?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. The President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Ian McLachlan, after many overtures, has now decided that the conservatives are too hopeless for him to run for them but he has dropped the pretence about non-political politics and is co-ordinating an anti-Government campaign with the anti-democratic Queensland Premier. In a classic example of political blackmail, Mr McLachlan has indicated that, if the honourable members for Ballarat, Bendigo, McEwen, Rankin and Eden-Monaro do not support New Right policies, they will face an expensive advertising campaign against them. No one else has to do this-not the Sinclair Nationals, the Joh Nationals or the Howard Liberals. Only the Labor Party is targeted. Mr McLachlan wants a Howard-Bjelke-Petersen government. Is that not marvellous! That should put the fear of God into everyone.

ANSWER.PARA: If Mr McLachlan is to campaign with the Queensland Premier, he must accept his policies. We know that the Queensland Premier has quite a few policies-cars which run on water and that sort of thing-but the only thing that he has consistently promised for a while is a flat tax. At least he has a tax policy-the Liberals do not even have one yet. As I have said over and over again, a flat tax would cost farmers money. A taxpayer on average farm income this year would pay $1,200 per year more under a 25 per cent flat tax than under the Government's tax scales. As well as this, tax averaging would also go with a flat tax, and that would result in a total loss to farmers of almost $300m-just to reduce taxes for the rich such as Mr McLachlan and a handful of rich farmers and the corrupt Queensland Premier's corrupt white-shoe brigade. The same point applies much more broadly than just to farmers in the five electorates that Mr McLachlan is targeting. A 25 per cent flat tax in 1984-85 would have cost all residents of Eden-Monaro an average of $495 each. That would be a total of $19.8m for the electorate as a whole. In the electorate of Ballarat, it would have cost every taxpayer $520 more; in Bendigo it would have cost $586; in McEwen $367; and wait for it, in Rankin it would have cost $764 more. That is what the Queensland Premier wants to impose on his people in Queensland. The New Right wants wages of $171.30 a week, while Mr Bjelke-Petersen wants his flat tax. The Opposition is selling the nonsense that families somehow do not receive wages-we have to be tougher on wages, but we have to be pro-family. As I said yesterday, most families that I know depend on wages and salaries.

Mr McLachlan also wants to pay for the abolition of the fuel excise by abolishing all Commonwealth health benefits. That is supposed to reduce inflation-but it would not. Abolition of fuel excises would reduce the consumer price index by less than 2 per cent immediately, and by about 4 per cent over a period of time, while abolishing the Commonwealth health benefits would increase the CPI by some 6 per cent immediately. Therefore, Mr McLachlan's logic is to increase the CPI and interest rates by 4 per cent this year and by 2 per cent over a slightly longer period, and also to have an inequitable and expensive health system available only to the wealthy. That is a sort of nonsense, muddled thinking, double-talk and double-think that will be rejected by the Australian people on 11 July.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to report to the House on the eighteenth meeting of the South Pacific Forum which I attended in Apia, Western Samoa on 29 and 30 May and hereby table the communique of the meeting. Honourable members will find in the communique an account of the various significant decisions taken, all of them by consensus, at the Apia meeting. I would like in this statement to highlight the matters of principal interest from Australia's perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: The Chairman of the Forum, the Prime Minister of Western Samoa, correctly observed in his opening statement that the circumstances under which this Forum took place were unprecedented and unusually testing. He did not mean by this-nor do I-solely the challenges posed by recent events in Fiji. There of course remain other major issues in the region, both political issues such as New Caledonia and economic challenges arising in large part from the vulnerability of the region to international economic fluctuations and changes. This was not, therefore, a `one issue' meeting for any of the members, Australia included. Accordingly, while the matter of Fiji has tended understandably enough to dominate perceptions of the Apia forum, I took on behalf of the Australian Government a keen interest in the opportunities for promoting co-operation with our Pacific friends and neighbours across the whole range of shared concerns. Given the particular significance of the Apia forum I wish to say how especially valu- able it was to have the active support and involvement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). Bill Hayden played an invaluable role both within the Forum proper and in bi- lateral discussions with heads of government, other foreign Ministers and senior figures present in Apia and I pay full tribute to him.

Although not, as I said, by any means the only item, developments in Fiji were clearly the major item at our meeting. Many hours were spent in serious and constructive consultation and deliberation on the matter, and appropriately so. What happened in Fiji a few weeks ago was a shattering event precisely because of its uniqueness in our region. The spectre of the military invasion of a free parliament and the overturning of a government by force is something tragically familiar in some other parts of the world. But it has been, before the Fiji coup, most happily unfamiliar to the South Pacific. The events in Fiji led to the unprecedented situation where Fiji was not present at the Forum.

Both the manner in which the Forum handled discussion of Fiji and the outcome of that discussion reflected great credit on the maturity of the Forum. It demonstrated once again the value of the Forum as the major voice for the expression of collective South Pacific opinion. Different emphases in the individual policies and interpretations of Forum countries regarding the situation in Fiji in no way prevented a full consensus and total unity on many essential propositions, as set out in the communique.

All members of the Forum expressed their concern and anguish about the overthrow of the elected Government in Fiji. We all expressed the hope for a peaceful and satisfactory solution. The Forum expressed willingness to provide whatever help it might be able to lend. It was decided that the Chairman of the Forum would request the Governor-General of Fiji to indicate to the Forum the forms of assistance he considered most appropriate.

Specifically we decided that, should the Governor-General of Fiji indicate that such a Forum initiative would be constructive and of assistance, the Forum would send a mission to Fiji. Such a mission would be led by me and comprise the Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands and the Director of the South Pacific Bureau for Economic Co-operation, the Secretariat of the Forum. The mission would hold discussions with all parties in Fiji with a view to attempting to facilitate processes leading to a resolution of current problems. It was further decided that should the Governor-General of Fiji respond with a request for assistance additional to this, or assistance of a different kind, then the Chairman of the Forum would communicate such a request to Forum Heads of Government. The Director of the SPEC would co-ordinate a response.

What we had here then was an effort to reach out to Fiji, to indicate clearly not only concern but willingness to help. Once these ideas, including the idea of a mission, were put forward by others, Australia was a very active participant in the development of the initiative, as of course we should be given our considerable interests and our regional role.

There has been a message from the Governor-General of Fiji to the Chairman of the Forum which politely declines the idea of a mission. As we understand it, however, this was in response to informal soundings at a very preliminary stage of thinking about the idea of a mission. Now that the Forum has taken its final decisions, as described in the communique, a further exchange of a more definitive kind should take place.

It may be that further contact between the Forum Chairman and the Governor-General will confirm, contrary to our hopes, the initial reaction of the Governor-General. In that case there are two points I would want to emphasise. First, for Australia's part, we would wish Fiji to regard the offer of assistance as being on the table, there to be picked up if and when Fiji considers this would be useful. Second, such a reaction from Fiji would obviously in no way negate the credit properly due to the Forum in forging an approach which, in my view, constitutes a very creative regional initiative. I am pleased that the Secretary General of the Commonwealth, in remarks reported today, sees the initiative in the same light. His support, as the Secretary General of an association of 49 nations throughout the world, is most useful.

There are several points about the character of this initiative which I wish to make absolutely clear. First, the proposed mission to Fiji was always of a contingent nature. No country in the Forum sought to impose such a mission. It was recognised by all of us from the very outset that it would be both inappropriate and utterly impractical for a mission to take place in the absence of agreement from the Governor-General of Fiji. This remains the case. Second, the spirit behind the Forum's offer to assist, through the mission or in other ways, was and remains to look to the future rather than to the past. This in no way means that Australia or any other Forum country which felt deeply disturbed by the military coup in Fiji now changes its reaction to that event. But we wish to facilitate solutions, not just condemn the events which have precipitated the current problem in Fiji. This is clearly in the interests of Australia, of Fiji and of the region. Australia and other Forum members have been well served over the years by harmonious social and political circumstances in Fiji. The system of constitutional democracy existing hitherto in Fiji has been central to that harmony. Just as turning away from that principle would adversely affect our interests, so a return to democratic principle would serve them.

Third, the mission would seek to impose no particular solution. In leading such a mission to Fiji I would carry no pre-set formula. It would be a matter of talking and listening to all the parties, seeking to understand their positions and concerns and trying to see whether, out of such processes of discussion, there may be the possibility of some common ground. This is entirely consistent with previously stated Australian policy. We have said that the exact means of restoring democratic processes in Fiji must be principally a matter for the people of Fiji themselves. We have said that Australia is flexible about precise solutions, within a framework of consistency with basic democratic principle.

Fiji should therefore understand that Australia seeks to lay down no blueprint, that we will not interfere or coerce, and that we are more than ready to help in the context of the Forum intiative. But it should also understand that it is simply inevitable that the quality of Australia-Fiji relations will be profoundly influenced by whether there is or is not a return to basic democratic principle. May I further suggest that this question will profoundly affect Fiji's own interests, in terms of both its domestic well-being and its international acceptance. In all respects Fiji should, I believe, perceive its interests to be served by the opening and the opportunity which the Forum has provided.

There is one final comment on the issue of Fiji which I wish to make. It was helpful for Mr Hayden and me to be able to speak to our regional colleagues from a position of broad national consensus in Australia on this issue, which is so important to Australia's national interest. I take this opportunity to acknowledge the support which the Government has received from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on the central issues of the Fiji crisis.

I turn now to other important matters which were discussed at the Forum. Again at Apia, New Caledonia was a matter of considerable significance. It was thoroughly discussed. The decisions reached by the Forum were both principled and relevant to the current situation. I noted at the Forum that Australia had been consistent in support for an early transition to independence in New Caledonia, which would properly recognise the multi-racial nature of its community. I said that we believed that Apia should build upon the results of the Forum in Suva last year, which centred upon the decision to seek re-inscription of New Caledonia on the UN list of non-self-governing territories, as well as the helpful meeting in Auckland in March of this year of Forum Foreign Ministers.

I noted that the referendum to be held in New Caledonia later this year, in French terms, would clearly be boycotted by the FLNKS. In those circumstances France must address itself to a simple question: What steps does it propose to take following a referendum which will clearly lack validity and credibility, in an environment then more conducive to internal and external forces dedicated to the instruments of violence? It is the Government's view that France should, instead, involve itself fully in the well-established United Nations decolonisation processes. I re-affirmed at the Forum the Government's total commitment to non-violent means of bringing about political change. Notwithstanding French reluctance thus far to enter into dialogue with the Forum, it continues to be actively interested in entering into such dialogue.

Honourable members will find that each of these points is embodied in the Forum position described in the communique. South Pacific opinion is united around a position which is firm, realistic and responsible. I am sure that the Forum will continue to be united in the management of this issue internationally, including at the United Nations. It is my Government's very strong hope that France will think again about the course on which it is embarked and pay the closest attention to the clearly expressed views of the countries of the region.

I now come to another matter of special importance to the Government, namely, external developments affecting regional security. The subject of regional security was raised by the Chairman of the Forum when heads of government gathered at Apia. We were able to have a full and fruitful discussion. One aspect was the interest which had been expressed by some Forum countries to a senior Australian official, during a recent and extensive visit to the region, in receiving more information on international developments which impact on regional security. This was a valuable suggestion and one which was given concrete form, at Australia's initiative, in the Apia meeting. The Forum has agreed to establish a system designed to improve the volume, the relevance and the timeliness of information exchanges in the area of security, broadly defined.

A range of developments in the outside world clearly impact on the security of South Pacific countries, in terms of both national security and defence, and economic security. Libyan behaviour provides a recent example, and this particular matter was fully aired in the discussions in Apia. But the new system is not confined to any single security issue and will, I hope, be wide-ranging in scope. The system will include several elements. There will be a meeting of officials in late 1987 to exchange information and to discuss relevant international developments, and also to establish a list of subjects on which Forum countries consider that improved information exchange would be of value. This can be refined and updated at later meetings. Countries with more extensive diplomatic representation outside the region should set up procedures to share the reporting they receive on relevant subjects, to the extent practicable. My Government, for its part, will now move to set up such a procedure.

There could be value in ad hoc meetings when it is considered that a particular international development has occurred on which Forum countries would benefit from a quick pooling of information and exchange of assessments. Another element has as its starting point the fact that some Forum countries, because of their greater resources, have a greater capability to analyse international developments and trends than do others. I said to colleagues at the Forum that we would be happy to try to assist by producing assessments of developments of special interest in response to requests. Another part of the system will be visits by analysts to exchange and discuss information with colleagues from other Forum countries. I believe this has excellent potential to develop over time into a useful new dimension of the already wide-ranging co-operation that exists on a day to day basis between Forum countries. The Forum will review the system of information exchange at its 1988 meeting.

I noted at the beginning of my statement the vital importance to Forum countries of economic issues. That is true for all member countries, no matter their size; but it is particularly the case for the smaller island countries whose economies are narrowly based and fragile. The difficulties of Forum countries are, for example, dramatically evident from an examination of the drastic decline in international commodity prices in the 1980s. An example of that may be gained from the fact that, for the two major commodities, from an index figure of 100 for 1980 the index figure for the third quarter of 1986 was down to about 33. That gives some indication of the massive decline in the prices they receive for their major export commodities. We are all aware of the profound impact of this situation on the Australian economy. On smaller economies, as I think can be appreciated, it can be absolutely disastrous. I explained to Forum colleagues the strenuous efforts made by Australia to combat protectionism in international agricultural trade, including through the establishment of the Cairns Group. The Forum communique, it will be noted, lends welcome support to our efforts.

I cannot emphasise too strongly that it is absolutely incumbent on the major trading countries to heed the impact which their decisions have on the smaller countries in our regional neighbourhood, and elsewhere. As the communique frankly notes, the ramifications can be highly dangerous politically as well as economically. Other concerns of the Pacific Island countries noted in the communique, for example illegal fishing by outside powers, are entirely legitimate and shared by Australia.

I assured the Forum that Australia continued to recognise its own obligations towards the region, as one of the developed Forum countries, in terms of development assistance and market access as well as other contributions such as our enhanced defence co-operation program. Regional countries very much appreciated Australia's Pacific patrol boat program, which is now well advanced, and the measures we are taking in a co-operative way to enhance fisheries surveillance.

The positive attention now being given to the potential for Pacific closer economic relations, a concept I first raised at the 1985 Forum, is particularly pleasing. A study is under way which will permit a wide range of options to be evaluated. It will be possible at the 1988 Forum to consider means of achieving closer economic relations on the basis of this detailed work.

The Forum considered a number of other matters and took decisions, as described in the communique. I draw attention to the important and most welcome widening of the Forum membership through acceptance of the Federated States of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands as full members; the references to strengthening the Forum as the paramount political institution in the South Pacific and increasing international recognition of it as such; the decision to establish a working group on terrorism and hijacking; and the developments which have taken place on three important multilateral agreements: The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty-the Treaty of Rarotonga-the South Pacific Regional Environmental Protection Convention and the Fisheries Treaty with the United States. It is with particular pleasure-pleasure that I am sure will be welcomed by members of the House-that I welcome the signature by the Solomon Islands during the Forum of the Treaty of Rarotonga. That signature brings support for the Treaty close to unanimity in the region. Only two countries have not to date signed the Treaty. I invite the attention of states outside the region, notably those eligible to sign the protocols to the Treaty, to the circumstance of near regional unanimity. I draw attention also to the renewal of my invitations to our South Pacific friends to participate in the Australian Bicentennial.

I began this statement by referring to the particular challenges facing the Forum meeting in Apia. I wish to close by saying that this was, in my judgment, the most constructive Forum I have attended. I judge it so because it faced those challenges, addressed them without division or acrimony and achieved consensus. Our relations with countries of the region have been further enhanced. Australia neither needs to nor should adopt a regional posture which is overbearing or condescending. The posture of my Government will continue to be one which combines the active defence and promotion of Australian interests with attentiveness and sensitivity to the views of our neighbours and willing acceptance of our obligations towards them.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There is substantial common ground between the Government and the Opposition regarding the events which have occurred in Fiji in recent weeks. I state at the outset that the Opposition shares the broad reaction of the Government to the overthrow of a democratically elected regime in Fiji. It shares the importance attached by the Government to exploring every possible method of having that properly elected government restored to its rightful position. As the Opposition in this Parliament, we welcome the opportunity for Australia to play a prominent role in the deliberations of the South Pacific Forum over the past few days. That will not be an occasion for any political point scoring about visits to the South Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government correctly expresses the views of the Australian public that the removal of any democratically elected government, wherever it may occur in the world, is something that people who believe in liberal democracy cannot possibly support. I hope, as does the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that when the more formal communication of the Forum proposal for a mission to go to Fiji is communicated to the Governor-General of Fiji, there will be a change of heart on the part of the Fijian Governor-General and that the mission to come from the Forum will be received. Hopefully, it will play a role in the restoration of a proper democratic government structure in that country.

It is appropriate that the Forum be used as the principal vehicle for trying to bring some form of international pressure on Fiji. The Opposition proposed that the Government at one stage give consideration to a mission comprising the foreign Ministers of four of the Commonwealth countries in the region. Although that was a proposal different in kind from the use of the Forum, our proposal had it in mind that if that mission had been received in Fiji it may well have reported to the meeting of the Forum which the Prime Minister has just visited.

Therefore, on behalf of the Opposition I say that on a matter which is so important to the region it has been possible for a degree of bipartisanship to be adopted in this Parliament and in the nation regarding the response. Our bipartisan bounty does not extend retrospectively to the lack of priority that the Government has given to the South Pacific over the last four years in its foreign policy. We note that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) took three years to visit the South Pacific; we note that the Foreign Minister stayed away for the duration of the immediate response of the Government to what was occurring in Fiji; and we also note with considerable interest the finger-waving exercise of the Foreign Minister when he returned home, making it perfectly clear for all and sundry that he was told to stay away by his Prime Minister. Everybody knows that that was the situation.

What the events in Fiji have brought home to the Australian public-I hope that they have brought this home to the Government; they have certainly brought it home to the Opposition-is that never again must any government in this country neglect the region immediately adjacent to it in its foreign policy and defence policy. One of the great foreign policy strikes against this Government is that it has accorded a greater priority to moralising about what might happen in South Africa and South America than it has to what is happening in our own backyard. That is something which must and should be held against this Government. It simply is not good enough for the Government, 18 months after the evidence was there, to discover suddenly that Libya is a problem. The Prime Minister, in the middle of the Fijian dispute, quite properly announced on behalf of the Australian Government that we would expel the Libyan People's Bureau from this country. It is a decision that the Opposition asked the Government to make more than a year ago. It is a decision, on the available evidence, that should have been taken a year ago. It is a decision that the Foreign Minister did not want to take a month ago. It is a decision which the Prime Minister took belatedly about 10 days ago. We support that decision.

I want to say only three other things. Firstly, our clout, our acceptability, and the likelihood of the Prime Minister's mission being received in Fiji would be greatly improved if the Government were to tell the Australian Council of Trade Unions in no uncertain terms to lift the bans from trade with Fiji. If the Prime Minister wants to go to Fiji pleading the cause-he would go with our support and good wishes-of elected governments and the need to restore elected governments, he would go there with greater authority if he could say on behalf of the Government of this country that as the elected government it is determining this country's foreign policy and no other section of the Australian community.

I think the second thing that the Government should do is to call off the diplomatic efforts it has used around the world to isolate the present regime in Fiji because, as much as we do not like it and as much as we have demonstrated our credentials of distaste, the situation now is that while we would like the restoration of the elected Fijian Government I think that, if the Prime Minister and the Government want to win diplomatic acceptance of the Prime Minister's mission, they must change and adapt their diplomatic strategy. They must recognise and deal with the reality of who is in charge in Fiji and try to come to terms with, and recognise that, notwithstanding our shared distaste for what has occurred, they must deal with the situation that presently exists in that country.

The final thing that I will say on behalf of the Opposition is that the Prime Minister's address to this House included reference to a nuclear free South Pacific. On behalf of the Opposition I point out that while we share to the full the Government's stated position on nuclear testing in the South Pacific-a position established by the Fraser Government, in turn copying the position taken by the Whitlam Government, and in turn that position has been taken by the Hawke Government and the same position will be taken by the next coalition government in this country-we do not share the naive faith of the Government and members of the Australian Labor Party in the value of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. We believe that while it has some commendable things to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to renege on the treaty?

—I say to the honourable member for Melbourne and to all other honourable members of the Labor Party that, while it has some commendable things to say about the disposal of nuclear waste, which we support, and it has commendable things to say about nuclear testing, which we support, it can in its terms and provisions interfere with the proper discharge of the treaty obligations of our major defence partners. In those circumstances, the Liberal Party and the National Party in this Parliament will never support a treaty that could in any way interfere with the discharge of the United States of America's obligations under the ANZUS Treaty. That is why we remain against that treaty.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to show restraint with equity.

In particular, the decision to defer the November pension adjustments has resulted in a loss of $25.62 for a single pensioner and $21.36 for each married pensioner. The prospect of a further deferral of the May adjustment will result in the loss of another $35.10 for a single pensioner and $29.10 for each married pensioner.

When you are scrimping to make ends meet, as is the case with many pensioners, you can't afford such a cut in living standards. Pensioners are looking for a new deal from politicians-more of the same is not good enough!
Your petitioners request an immediate return to payment of May and November C.P.I. increases, and as is duty bound will ever pray the Government grant this request now.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite,Mr Donald Cameron and Mr Nehl.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities. They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of Post Office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Harry Edwards and Mr Slipper.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Halverson and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Two Dollar Coin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That, as a consequence of the Hawke Government's decision to introduce a two dollar coin in 1988,

Whereas the introduction of a one dollar coin was only a twofold increase in the maximum value of coinage, the elimination of the two dollar note represents a five-fold increase before a note can be used.

It will have taken eighteen years from decimalisation to go from the fifty cent piece as the highest value coin to a one dollar coin, but only a further four years to replace the two dollar note with a coin.
The lowest value paper note will be five dollars, forcing a dramatic increase in the weight of coinage carried and dislocation of the retail industry.
Many people, particularly the elderly, will mistake the value of the coin for that of another lower value coin just as many now confuse a one dollar coin with the ten cent piece.

That the addition of two new coins in four years creates the biggest number of coins in circulation at any time in Australia's history and will lead to the removal of the one cent and two cent coins; this will accelerate the cost of living, particularly the cost of food where numerous items are involved and future price rises would need to be five cent increases on every item on every occasion.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the proposed two dollar coin not be proceeded with by the Hawke Government, and no future Government proceed with this proposal for several years.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Business Offices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we oppose plans by Telecom Australia to close many of the Telecom Business Offices (TBO's) and replace them with a reduced service to be co-located with the District Customer Services Office. We believe the public should be able to make telephone bill payments, applications for new services, selection of telephone and complaints, in person at a convenient and easily accessible location. Telecom Business Offices provide this service, and therefore it is wrong that their contribution and performance will only be assessed on their sales revenue.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: instruct the management of Telecom Australia to immediately cease all action to close any Telecom Business Offices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act 1953.
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Flags Amendment Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Wannon electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's ID card proposal is the most far reaching and intrusive piece of Australian legislation ever, and that on all the evidence available will not tackle in the most cost-efficient and effective manner tax and social security fraud.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject Labor's ID card proposal to prevent a gross waste of taxpayers' money and a significant infringement of civil liberties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned by the threat to social morality and the welfare of children, posed by the unrestricted importation, distribution and sale of X-rated pornographic video material in and from the Australian Capital Territory.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: National Identification Numbering System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australian Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Charge
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

1. the annual administration charge will inevitably restrict access to higher education for a range of disadvantaged groups, particularly women, rural dwellers and some low income earners.
2. students will be deterred from study because of the probable escalation in the charge in future Budgets, prohibiting students ability to plan the long term costs of their education.

3. the charge is ill-conceived and unfairly penalises part-time students, age pensioners and Austudy/Abstudy beneficiaries who, in many cases, have to wait for months for reimbursement of the charge-amongst others.
4. the imposition of the charge is contrary to the education provisions of the ALP/ACTU Accord and ALP policy which states that the party ``will maintain the provision of free tertiary education''.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the annual administrative charge for higher education students be immediately withdrawn and that subsequent funding shortfalls be met from general Government revenue.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Pacific Highway Improvements

That the North Coast section of the Pacific Highway, from a point just south of Port Macquarie and just north of Woolgoolga, is in urgent need of major road improvement works in order to bring it up to road safety standards.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government immediately divert national highway funds or make available other funds towards the improvement of this section of the Pacific Highway.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs

Any proposals to abolish the Department of Veterans' Affairs gravely concern ex-servicemen, ex-servicewomen and their families, because they renege on clear and unequivocal commitments from various Commonwealth Governments to properly care for Australia's Veterans.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to ensure that the Department of Veterans' Affairs continues to exist as a separate and distinct Department of State servicing the needs of veterans and their families.

penalises small business and farming enterprises,
discourages long-term investment,
hinders capital formation,

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled, we the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher call upon all Members to pay due respect to pensioners and concessional card holders and cease the constant erosion of our entitlements by the Hawke Government.

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular.
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;

the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

the dependent spouse rebate be retained;

Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT'S INTEREST RATE AND TAXATION POLICIES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the House discussing a definite matter of public importance proposed to Madam Speaker by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey).

Discussion of Matter of Public Importance Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The devastating effect of the Hawke Government's high interest rate and taxation policies as evidenced by the record rate of bankruptcies among small businesses and farmers.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I will never say another bad word about him-how is that? I thank the Government. I recognise the mistake that was made in my office today, and I thank the Government for its accommodation. May we now call off all bets?

SPEECH.PARA: This year, 8,000 Australians will become bankrupt-the highest figure in Australia's history, both numerically and per capita. Bankruptcy statistics are a phenomenon of wage earners and small family businesses. The big companies, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) so frequently quote to support their economic policies, do not go bankrupt; they have receivers appointed or they are liquidated. Therefore, bankruptcy figures are a direct indicator of the welfare of our vital small business sector-in which, I might add, some 650,000 businesses employ fewer than five people.

I say that the figures are an indicator only because not all small business failures result in bankruptcy. The figure for failure is much larger than that record 8,000 bankruptcies. The President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Ian McLachlan, said just this morning that the failures are of `unbelievable numbers'. In many cases, the people concerned simply sell their assets and pay whatever debts they can. The big guys usually get in first; the small business creditors know that sending someone bankrupt will not get them anything anyway, so they simply leave the matter lie. These people for the rest of their lives have debts which they cannot pay. Of course, it is a great human tragedy. One of the more notable big guys is the Commissioner of Taxation. I am advised by the accountancy profession that approximately 70 per cent of current small business bankruptcy is brought about either on the petition of the Commissioner of Taxation or because he is the principal creditor. In other words, the Treasurer has spread the virus and his grim reaper is prepared to preside over the post-mortem to collect the pound of flesh.

The viruses that are destroying small business and farmers are taxation and interest rates. Both are the result of excessive government spending and borrowing. We heard the Treasurer today tell us about his wonderful economic management. He reverses the facts. If we look at the graphs we see that Mr Gough Whitlam was the person who first blew out government expenditure and put burdens on the Australian economy from which it has never recovered. We see that by a careful step by step approach the Fraser Government gradually hauled back that blowout and was starting to get this country in some sort of shape. In one year alone, to give an example, the entire Australian wheat crop was taken away. There was no production of real dollars in that area. That is what the Treasurer is referring to, of course, when he claims that the Australian people have bad economic management. One cannot manage money if it is not placed in the till. The only time during which there was negative growth in the Australian economy was when the crops did not grow. It was not the result of problems existing in the Parliament or in the Administration at the time.

When the crops did grow, when the international recession ended, what did the Hawke Administration do? It acted like we were still in a recession. It borrowed $17,000m in two years so that it could have a big splurge. The result was the same as for any small businessman who followed that practice. We had the party, now we are trying to pay the debts when the opportunities are not as good as they were before. There is no need to blame the foreigners. The reality is that people were brought to this position by the decisions of government.

As an aside, I refer to the fraudulent advertising with which the Australian Labor Party and its gung ho advertising agent have commenced the Labor campaign. I refer in particular to the notorious Westpac Banking Corporation advertisement, which quoted the `Westpac New York Chief'. Of course, the person referred to in that ad, Garry Egan, is not a chief; in fact, he is barely an Indian. The Labor Party has been publicly rebuked by Westpac management. If I were a specialist money market dealer, without the concerns for more ordinary Australians that the institution of Westpac obviously has, I would like the Hawke-Keating Government. What other government of a developed country is presently forcing its citizens to pay 20 per cent interest rates? What other government instructs its Reserve Bank to operate in such a fashion as to guarantee the market for these money dealers? What other government in Australia's history has borrowed $24,000m in four years from those money markets and has paid out $8,000m per annum in interest? That figure of $8,000m represents 11.3 per cent of Budget revenue. It is the second largest direct government expenditure item. It was the fifth largest item under the Fraser Government.

There is little doubt about the massive paper shuffling profits of the money dealers or the stock dealer with the big cigar who is the partner in the Labor Party's advertising agency. There is little doubt about their profit or their love. They are the paper shufflers. But there is now compelling evidence of the hardship and the failure amongst small businesses and their customers. The customers, of course, are ordinary Australian families. The problem is interrelated. One cannot shift an additional $152 of family income per month, via home interest rates, into the hands of the financial institutions without a corresponding reduction in spending at the corner store. One cannot shift an additional $50 of family income per month to the Tax Commissioner without a corresponding reduction in turnover at the clothing or shoe store. One cannot destroy the value of our currency by irresponsible economic management without rapid increases in prices of imported goods and the consequent destruction of thousands of small businesses selling applicances, motor vehicles and farm machinery.

Under the Hawke Government the price of a Holden Commodore manual has increased from $10,500 to $16,500-60 per cent higher than the price when the Fraser Government left office. The cost of televisions, fridges and washing machines has increased by huge amounts. The results are easy to find. Nobody is making any sales. Last month the car industry recorded its lowest sales for 20 years. It is quite easy to see why. People have less spending power and prices are high. It is no wonder that the Australian Labor Party's big spending advertising man has been told to rethink his advertising strategy of `the worst is behind us'. It is no wonder that the Labor Government does not want people to contemplate for too long on that thought and make the obvious judgment that under this Labor Government there is no light at the end of the tunnel.

That is not to say that under Labor there is not a promise of a light at the end of the tunnel. With Hawke and Keating there is a promise about everything. But all of those promises carry a use-by date. I do not think that the Labor Party would wish to concentrate the public's mind on the value of its promises for too long during the election campaign. If it did, the public might be caused to remember Labor's promises of falling interest rates, lower taxes, and the lulu of all times-`there will be no capital gains tax'.

Elections are times for a new deal. Let us look briefly at the mandate that the Australian Labor Party seeks for small business. It seeks a mandate to introduce its mini-Budget and thus increase Federal Government charges via Telecom Australia and Australia Post by $400m; to increase State government charges by up to $1,000m because it has reduced Federal government grants to the States; and to borrow a further $3,000m to fund the next deficit, with the consequent pressure on domestic interest rates. Of course, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is constantly telling us that the next deficit will be only one per cent of gross domestic product. That is a nice interesting figure. No one understands it but it does not sound much. In fact it is $3,000m of additional borrowing. But, worst of all, the Prime Minister has promised us no new taxes. If ever I have seen a sign for the future, that promise worries me most. That is because every time the Prime Minister promises no new taxes, we get more taxes. Every time the Prime Minister promises that interest rates will go down, they go up. Every time the Prime Minister promises no early election, we have an early election. It is no wonder that the Governor-General of Fiji does not want him over there. He just might promise them peace and prosperity, and that would be the end of that.

The Prime Minister also wants a mandate to introduce his industrial relations legislation. In simple terms, this legislation will deny small businesses, which are subject to illegal action by union bosses, the right to redress in ordinary courts in Australia. Instead of being able to put their case before judges appointed for their experience and skills in the legal profession, they will be placed before judges selected for their skills in industrial bargaining. There is only one source of such people-the trade union movement. Caesar will sit in judgment on Caesar. But, of course, small businesses will be the losers. All that a trade union needs to impose its will on a small business is time. Today small businesses meet their financial commitments on a monthly basis, whether they be lease payments or other forms of payments to their banks. Small businesses cannot afford interruptions of more than a couple of weeks to their cash flow.

The Industrial Relations Bill, for which the Government requests a mandate at the coming election, guarantees a trade union the time to bludgeon a small business into submission before a matter can be taken to court. It is ridiculous to suggest that a small business could sue for damages when it is already broke. Small businesses such as owner-driver truckies and subcontractors will continue to buy a union ticket or a union superannuation agreement as a licence to work. But, without the protection of our now common law courts, small businesses will continue to suffer unfairly. It was not long ago that the Prime Minister in this House referred to someone in Queensland as a fascist. Nobody on our side of politics approves of extremists, whether they be fascists or communists. But the reality of totalitarian regimes is that they cannot exist where there is a common law. The best defence we can have from totalitarianism is a common law and proper legally trained people with the traditions of the law behind them.

Let me tell the House of the other mandate which the Labor Party seeks. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is sitting in the chamber. The Labor Party seeks a mandate to introduce an identity card and tells people that honest taxpayers have nothing to fear. Clauses 40 to 50 of the legislation impose higher fines on honest people than on anybody else. For example, clause 49 of the Australia Card Bill provides that an honest and decent Australian employer, including a householder, who has never committed an act to defraud the Australian Taxation Office or the welfare system, faces a fine of between $20,000 and $100,000 for simply failing to request the production of an identity card from a new employee and/or failing to pass on that information to the Commissioner of Taxation. There is no obligation in the legislation that it be passed on to the Department of Social Security, which, of course, might be very interested in the activities of that employee, particularly if he or she were still on the dole. I wonder why such honest and decent Australians warrant fines under this legislation which are between four and 20 times higher than the fines applicable under clause 166 for direct action to defraud by giving false information to obtain a card. In other words, the real crook is fined about $5,000 and the person who makes a mistake and fails to ask a new employee for the identity card gets fined $20,000 to $100,000. The same provisions apply to honest and decent real estate agents, stockbrokers, stock and station agents, produce merchants and banks. All these people will be fined for failing to report on their clients. They will not be charged with any act on their part of tax dodging or welfare fraud, but they will be fined the highest penalties under the legislation for their failure to report to the Commissioner of Taxation, and the Commissioner of Taxation alone, on the activities of their business clients, big or small.

In the last minute available to me, let me put down the record of this Labor Government and why small business is in such terrible shape. The last Fraser Government raised $44,000m in taxation. Just four years later the Budget now being concluded will raise $71,000m in taxation. During that four-year period the Government has been forced to borrow $24,000m, using our children as security, to fund the difference between its expenditure and the revenue it has raised through tax. It has increased the interest bill to $8,000m to do that. It has seen the international indebtedness of Australia grow from $35 billion to $105 billion--

The good old days, when we had rising demand and rising prices and we did not really have to try hard to make a quid in this country, are gone. It is a different environment nowadays. It is very much more competitive, because all our competitors today used to be our customers yesterday. The fall in our commodity prices is doubly hazardous for Australia because we never equipped ourselves for the business environment of today. The Liberal Party and the National Party were happy just to send wheat, wool and rocks overseas, and they never bent their minds to the hard task of establishing a manufacturing and productive investment base in this country. In many ways the Liberals are like old businessmen. They are in a time warp and they cannot really see that times have changed. They cannot see that we cannot send rocks, wheat and wool overseas and hope to sustain a high standard of living. As I say, the honourable member for O'Connor talked about business.
