TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 280th report of the Committee, relating to the Defence Science and Technology Organisation task cost management.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee's 280th report outlines the findings of the Committee's review of an efficiency audit by the Auditor-General on task cost management in the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. The Auditor-General's report, tabled on 19 March 1986, revealed inadequacies in procedures for estimating, allocating and controlling the use of resources within DSTO. The inadequacies, combined with the absence of an effective management information system at DSTO's central office, reduced management's ability to monitor and control the deployment of resources effectively at laboratory level.

SPEECH.PARA: DSTO has been the subject of several reviews since 1979 with the result that at the time of the audit DSTO was addressing a number of shortcomings identified by the Auditor-General. The Committee notes that the Department of Defence has taken action, or is taking action, on the eight recommendations the Auditor-General made in his report. To gain a better appreciation of DSTO's administration and facilities, the Committee inspected the five major DSTO research laboratories in Melbourne and in Salisbury, near Adelaide. During the inspections several matters were raised with the Committee including the commercialisation of DSTO's research and development, recruitment and retention of staff, and the provision of advice by DSTO to the armed services, a matter which had arisen during our previous inquiry into defence project management.

All DSTO laboratories raised the issue of the gap between the research and development conducted by DSTO and the marketing of the results of that research and development. The Department of Defence does not have the entrepreneurial expertise or overall cohesion between its marketing areas to maximise the commercial potential of DSTO's research and development. There are several options which would assist in closing this marketing gap. One is a proposal suggested by the Aeronautical Research Laboratory-ARL-that a private company, to be called Aerotech, be set up to act as an agent for ARL. Aerotech would seek contracts with national and international aerospace industry and would have the skills in marketing and in legal and financial administration that ARL lacks. Aerotech would retain a percentage of the gross revenue generated by the contracts it obtained and the balance would provide the resources for the Aerotech programs undertaken by ARL and other subcontractors.

The Committee is impressed with the Aerotech proposal; however, the Committee believes that it is essential that Aerotech be self-sufficient. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended the implementation of the Aerotech proposal with the proviso that Aerotech must be commercially successful-that is, able to cover its own costs and provide income for ARL. The Committee believes companies similar to Aerotech could lead to greater commercialisation of the research and development efforts of the other DSTO laboratories. However, the Committee does not think it should be mandatory for the other laboratories to set up their own technology transfer companies. Without motivation and commitment on the part of the laboratories' staff such companies would fail.

The second solution suggested to the Committee during its inspections was the introduction of a `ferret' system similar to that adopted by the United Kingdom Ministry of Defence. Under this system representatives of private companies would be installed in DSTO laboratories to search for research and development tasks which have commercial potential. The companies would then make arrangements with industry to develop and manufacture the technology with a percentage of the resulting profit going to the investing laboratory. The Committee sees merit in the `ferret' system and considers that the success of the United States system and its applicability to Australian conditions should be investigated. The Committee believes that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce would be the most suitable organisation to examine the `ferret' system and has made a recommendation to this effect in its report.

The Committee believes the commercialisation of DSTO's research and development would be increased if there were a single marketing body involved instead of the present fragmented structure within the Department of Defence. Since the main concern of the Department of Defence is not the export of goods and in view of its lack of expertise in this field, the Committee thinks the marketing body should be within Austrade rather than Defence. I commend the report to honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In December 1984 Australian businessman, Mr Dick Smith, produced a book with the title Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom in which he strongly condemned the nature and extent of the regulatory activities of the Department of Aviation. I commend him on his forthrightness. In view of extensive public and media interest created by the book, the Committee resolved on 28 February 1985 to conduct an inquiry into the matters raised by Mr Smith and into the operational regulatory decisions of the Department of Aviation. The Committee's invitation for public comment met with a substantial response with some 800 submissions, over 1,000 letters and many telephone calls. The submissions canvassed a comprehensive range of issues, generally critical of the Department of Aviation and its approach to these issues. The Committee was impressed by the volume and intensity of the criticisms of the Department of Aviation. It was clear that all was not well in the Australian aviation industry and in the relationship between the Department and the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sub-Committee concentrated on one particular case study detailed in Mr Smith's book. This case study centred on the Darling Harbour helicopter landing site in Sydney and generated particular public controversy in the months following the receipt of submissions. The Sub- Committee inspected the Darling Harbour environment and held public hearings in Canberra and Sydney. The Committee presented a report about this particular matter in November 1985 entitled `No Port in a Storm'. It contained evidence of deficiencies and inconsistencies in the Department's decision-making procedures. The Sub-Committee also undertook a review of an Auditor-General's efficiency audit report into the installation and maintenance of airways facilities by the Department of Aviation. The inquiry involved the inspection of airways facilities in Victoria, New South Wales and the Northern Territory and was reported to the House in May 1986. The Government's response to both these reports is awaited. The Sub-Committee was naturally anxious to pursue the many other matters raised by Mr Smith and in the submissions, and indicated in the interim report that it intended to pursue an extensive program of hearings in all State capitals in 1986. The Committee engaged a consultant to examine the submissions prior to public hearings. Another consultant was asked to provide a review of progress in the Sydney helicopter industry a year after the Committee's report. Copies of both consultants' reports are appended to this statement.

The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) also recognised the problems the industry was encountering with his Department, and he moved to introduce remedial measures. On 22 October 1986 he announced five major decisions, as follows: Firstly, an in-principle decision to set up a civil aviation corporation to provide and operate the civil airways system in Australia; secondly, an in-principle decision to set up a review panel to consider proposed regulatory changes; thirdly, a complete review of the air navigation regulations and other subordinate orders and instructions; fourthly, a review of criteria for establishing and maintaining airways facilities; and fifthly, an efficiency audit of air space usage.

The Committee informally sought the views of a number of aviation industry spokesmen about their perceptions of the adequacy of the Minister's announcements and found that they met with support, qualified only by a certain cynicism that such dramatic positive changes would ever come to pass given the past track record of the Department. The Committee has given consideration to the continuing conduct of its inquiry in the context of these developments. On the one hand, the Committee is conscious that the aviation industry and many individuals have high expectations of its inquiry. A lot of effort was expended by many people in putting comprehensive submissions to the Committee for its consideration. In fact, analysis of submissions by the Committee's consultant indicated that some 142 warranted further examination at public hearings in all States and the Northern Territory. On the other hand, the Committee recognises that such a heavy program of hearings could involve the Committee in duplication of the reviews already proposed by the Minister, and accordingly may not be the best use of committee resources.

The Committee believes that its most appropriate course of conduct in this regard is to encourage the Minister to implement his proposals promptly and for the Committee to closely monitor the success of the various measures in bringing about the type of changed environment in the aviation industry so strongly argued for in submissions. To those who provided submissions to the Committee we wish to say that we are not complacent about the problems drawn to our attention, nor the apparent need for radical change. The Committee has not terminated its inquiry but merely postponed it. We will be particularly wary of an `old wine in new bottles' situation arising under the guise of progress. Dick Smith saw his book as a catalyst for change. That change is now being achieved. The Committee will monitor developments to ensure that Australian aviation, and not the bureaucracy, is the beneficiary. I seek leave to present a copy of the statement together with the attachments.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate so far. This matter has caused a fair amount of discussion for a number of years and I can well understand honourable members feeling that there needs to be a balance when we are looking at legislation that allows interception in certain circumstances, but certainly prohibits it in all other circumstances. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has moved a second reading amendment which objects to the delay in introducing the legislation and also refers to the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Alleged Telephone Interceptions, which is now known as the Stewart Royal Commission. I will again mention some of the matters that the honourable gentleman himself mentioned regarding time.

SPEECH.PARA: I would say that the honourable gentleman felt he was entitled to say that the Government was tardy in looking at the issue that arose from what was known as the Age tapes. It would be far more accurate to call them the Age transcripts because there were virtually no tapes. The fascinating thing about this matter is that all the information was obtained by illegal intercepts, from tapes that were known, were in existence and were shown to the Australian Federal Police. The Stewart Royal Commission report indicates that they were in existence for 15 years from 1967 onwards. I invite the honourable gentleman to address his mind to that position. Mr Justice Stewart found that, for 15 years, the New South Wales police, and perhaps police in other States, were illegally intercepting and obtaining information. He further found that the information was very valuable, that it related to a number of prosecutions and that it gave a fair amount of criminal intelligence; nevertheless, it was illegal and the taping should not have happened.

Mr Justice Stewart felt, with some justification, that the police were obliged to carry out those illegal intercepts because of the frustrations they felt in being unable to get access to the telephone communications system. I ask the honourable member for North Sydney what applications were made to the Fraser Government from 1977 to 1983. That is a very relevant period. The Age transcripts relate to tapes that were illegally obtained and used in that period. I only say that because it is not fair to suggest that the delay in introducing this legislation has suddenly come about because the tapes brought to light evidence that could have otherwise been obtained legally. There was a 15-year cycle. There were at least over 200 intercepts, all illegal. A massive organisation was going on in New South Wales with apparently no one knowing about it, except when it came to Mr Justice Stewart. There was also a question of indemnities being granted. Mr Justice Stewart identified the problem. He made his report in April 1986.

I will again refer to what governments are obliged to do and what police forces are expected to do. The report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Ian Temby, dated July 1984, into what is called the Age materials-and that is a more appropriate description-went into a lot of detail about what was known at the time. If one looks at that report-and I will not delay the House for any length of time-one sees quite clearly that he obtained evidence from a large number of Federal Police officers in the period about which he is talking, 1979 to 1981, who had access to the tapes. They heard the tapes; they paid money for the tapes to a person called Irish, who happened to be a Sergeant Hawthorn, a police officer of New South Wales, who had the tapes. Is it not a bit late to suggest that the Government is a bit slow in this matter? I wonder what happened in the period when Police Commissioner Woods, Deputy Commissioner Farmer and Detective Sergeant Lewington all acknowledged that they had the tapes-the real evidence. We cannot find them now. What we found, at the end of some political scurrying, was what were called the Age tapes, which are a compilation, apparently, of the illegitimate tapes given to the Federal Police in the period I mentioned.

I do not accept that this Government should be impugned on the basis of delay. The most senior police officers in the Federal Police were listening to those tapes, paying money for them and getting permission to do so from the Commissioner at the time. That was not known to any member of the Government at the time. That is the problem we face on this issue. The matter should have been dealt with at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not known then.

—The honourable member for North Sydney said it was not known. He was not here. I cannot for the life of me accept that it was not known when a cash book showed a number of entries and the amounts of money that were paid from time to time. I do not accept that any legitimate organisation, such as a police force, would not be able to indicate the sort of intelligence it was using. From what Mr Justice Stewart said, the tapes that the Federal Police had have not yet been found. We cannot get them from the New South Wales police. They do not exist. We got a bastardised arrangement from the transcript of the so-called Age tapes, which was a compilation of them. The honourable member for North Sydney is well aware of the problems. When Mr Justice Stewart looked at this particular document, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Even in cases where a transcript appears to have been translated verbatim, there is no way, except in the few cases where tapes still exist, by which the Commission can ascertain whether the whole of the conversation has been transcribed . . .
He goes on to talk about all of the problems. He said that something had been omitted that may well change the whole meaning of the conversation. He said:
The Commission is not satisfied that the transcript material in summary form has been prepared with sufficient care to be affirmed as wholly accurate.

In other words, it would not be admissible as evidence. That is the sad story of a period when there was the opportunity, even though the information was illegally obtained, for the government of the time to be alerted to the fact that there was something dramatically wrong with what was happening in the New South Wales police force. It is no excuse for senior police officers to suggest that they thought the interceptions were carried out in a legal way. In what legal way could those interceptions have been carried out in that period? The police were on notice as to the position. They were paying money for the information. It is a sorry period, but I am citing it on the basis that it is not much good honourable members opposite coming in here berating a government which is having a fair bit of difficulty trying to convince those who are now interested in the matter, namely the State governments, that they ought to have access to interceptions on certain terms and on a certain basis. That is the reason for the delay.

The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) effectively put the point of view that when the Committee met it invited the State governments to come before it because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had asked them so to do to give their views, particularly on narcotics, and so that we might give them the opportunity to use interceptions. We received the most luke-warm and weak response that anybody could possibly imagine. The honourable member serialised the events. There was no answer from the Victorian Government or from the Tasmanian Government. The South Australian Government did not wish to avail itself of that position. The Northern Territory Government made no formal submission. The New South Wales Government wrote a letter; the Queensland Government did not really want to get involved in it, nor did the Western Australian Government. They are pretty bleak old responses. A political issue is involved in this.

I suppose that those who run governments are worried about the fact that they might get some political flak if it is thought that people's telephones can be intercepted-and so we all would. At the same time, the police forces are adamant that phone tapping is a very effective tool of trade in the pursuit of criminal activity. Stewart confirms that; so we have to get a balance. The police associations, I am pleased to note, support us. The Australian Police Ministers supported the Bill in a resolution passed as recently as 22 May. I can understand that, but the point of the history of the delay certainly should not be sheeted home to us. It comes back to the factors that should have been brought to notice in the period between 1979 and 1982. I reject that suggestion.

A number of other criticisms were raised about the Bill. These issues were based on the fact that perhaps an issue of a warrant might require judges to be caught up in determining whether an offence is a class 1 or a class 2 offence. The report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking suggested that there would be adequate protection for the citizen from the point of view of the gravity of the offence. I am very satisfied that the judiciary, both Federal and State, has the capacity to understand those problems. I do not see any particular difficulties there. I think we would overcome a lot of criticism that we might get if it were realised that there cannot be interceptions-unless there is an emergency-without a judicial survey of what is intended. The question, of course, was: What happens if there is an emergency? The Bill allows the Australian Federal Police to conduct interceptions without using Telecom Australia where a judge so orders. The circumstances in which this may happen are set out in proposed new section 48 of the Bill. The Federal Police may do this with the execution of warrants issued to any law enforcement agency.

There was also the argument that the State police should be able to intercept independently, but the Joint Select Committee recommended that all interceptions be conducted through the Australian Federal Police. Procedures are now in place that will guarantee an immediate facility. Once the connection is made the State police will have the opportunity to use that facility immediately, even though it would have been a Federal connection which is the appropriate thing to do.

Another question was: Should it be an offence to sell interception devices and should they be prohibited imports. We have not rejected the recommendation, but we have to draw the distinction between what is an interception device and what is a listening device. We can deal only with interception devices. We cannot deal with listening devices. We cannot deal with transmitters and things of that nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can deal with anything coming in or out.

—We were talking about the capacity of interception of the telecommunications system. That is where I think the difficulty is-whether we would not allow some, what we call, normal transmitters to come in-as happens now and whether we would allow what we call interception material to come in. So we do place the Customs people in some difficulty. The matter is not closed. We are saying that as we are dealing with interception material we cannot quickly identify we should not prohibit all devices from the point of view of transmission. That is the difficulty the Government has been advised of.

SPEECH.PARA: There was the question of the admissibility of illegally intercepted material. We make it very clear that the problems that we have faced in the past should not be faced in the future. From here on-and I make the caveat of course that current proceedings are excepted, and that relates to an amendment that the honourable gentleman wishes to move at the Committee stage-we will not have admitted into evidence illegally obtained material. The reason for that is that if we have legislation which says that there has to be a proper format, that there has to be a warrant, it would be counter-productive to use it if the evidence could be obtained in some other way. It would be counter-productive because we would still have to prosecute the person under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act for breaking that particular law even though, it may be argued, it might be of some significance in criminal detection. We have to get the law right. If we have law enforcement officers we expect them to carry out the law. I do not see any particular burden here.

This legislation is effective legislation. The States will find it relatively easy to use the facility. The arrangements are in place and they seem to be very practical. On that basis I see no reason why everybody would not, in the appropriate circumstances, follow the course in this legislation, seek the appropriate warrant and then be given the opportunity to have such a connection.

As I understand it, the circumstances in which warrants will be granted are not so numerous. They are somewhat expensive from a point of view of labour. It may well be that the average would be not more than one a month, at most. It is a necessary mechanism whereby law enforcement agencies can have intelligence and use that intelligence in the detection of crime and in the prevention of crime. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the offences are outlined in the legislation. They relate not only to narcotics but also to very serious offences such as murder, kidnapping and other such offences which might carry a penalty of seven years or more.

We will need to move some amendments which have been circulated. They relate to the fact that there needs to be some tidying up, particularly from the point of view of the gazettal of judges who might be eligible. The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) also proposed an amendment, which we will accept, about the police commissioner only or anybody authorised by him to deal with the question of warrants. I will be explaining the Government's position at the Committee stage. This legislation is certainly not before its time but there has been a fair amount of discussion. If there has been some difficulty in getting it accepted, basically it has been because of the hesitancy and the reluctance of the State governments to take up the offer made to them by the Prime Minister in 1985.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to move an amendment to clause 5 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill which will have the effect of making offences which can be the subject of interception surveillance offences which are punishable by not less than three years imprisonment. It would therefore substitute for the present structure in the Bill which sets up class 1 and class 2 offences and effectively puts a floor under the offences which can be examined save for one exception, to which I will refer in a minute, of seven years. If an offence is punishable by less than seven years imprisonment, it cannot be the subject of surveillance. Yet inconsistently enough, an offence which has been examined by the National Crime Authority under its special investigation powers and which may be punishable by three, four, five or six years can be the subject of surveillance. We see no reason to deal with the National Crime Authority in one way and then deal with all other offences in another way. We think it is better to approach things more in the spirit of Mr Justice Stewart's approach to matters, that is, to have broad criteria of what might be described as serious offences. Whenever one seeks to arrive at a cut-off point one must make an arbitrary judgment in the sense that one looks to a period of time which is the basis for the cut-off in dealing with criminal offences. Here we say that it should be three years in place of the Government's proposal. It is for that reason, therefore, that we will move this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me refer some offences punishable by more than three years but less than seven years imprisonment which, unless the subject of examination by the National Crime Authority, would not be caught; that is, they would not be subject to telephone interceptions. I refer to offences under the Crimes Act of the Commonwealth: False pretences, dealt with under section 29a of that Act and punishable by five years imprisonment; section 35, false testimony, punishable by five years imprisonment; section 36a, intimidation of witnesses, including the use of violence against witnesses, punishable by five years imprisonment; section 37, corruption of witnesses, punishable by five years imprisonment; and section 42, conspiracy to defeat justice, five years imprisonment. These are pretty important matters. Other offences include section 44, compounding or concealing indictable offences, punishable by three years imprisonment; section 69, making special paper, that is, for purposes preparatory to forgery, punishable by four years imprisonment; and, of course, those who aid and abet the commission of those offences are punishable by the same maximum periods of imprisonment as the principal offenders. Therefore, we believe that an amendment is required and we will propose the amendment which has been circulated in my name.

As we are dealing with clauses 1 to 20, I will also touch on other comments. During the second reading debate the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee)-and I am glad to see that he is present in the chamber-referred to something I said about interceptions in New York. He said:

. . . to suggest that the police force in New York can carry out intercepts on the majority of telephones in New York within 30 seconds is baloney. There is no way that that could be common practice in New York. I know that carrying out intercepts within 30 seconds is simply not on in Australia with the Telecom equipment that is installed.

That is a most telling admission because, if the honourable member for Dobell had listened carefully to what I had said, he would have heard that I was referring to emergency intercepts conducted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. If the honourable member wants to check on the accuracy of what I said, I suggest that he go to New York and see the head of counter-terrorism there and ask him about intercepts and how quickly they can be put on in emergency situations; and he will be told that they can get them on in under 30 seconds. Of course, we now understand that Telecom Australia cannot do that and, of course, it is that agency which will be required to put on the intercepts. Of course, we know that difficulties have been experienced in the past in the use of Telecom. I quote again from the comments of the honourable member for Dobell:
I know that carrying out intercepts within 30 seconds is simply not on in Australia with the Telecom equipment that is installed.

As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception, I suppose he knows what he is talking about. I will now move on and pick up something said by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) when he referred to time and went back to the Age material, and I agreed that it should properly be called the Age material. He said that these illegal intercepts had been taking place over many years. Well, of course, so they had.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stewart said that?
—Stewart said that.

—Order! I do not want honourable members interjecting across the table on this matter. I do not think that the honourable member for North Sydney should repeat other honourable members' speeches at the second reading stage. The matter before the Committee is the honourable member's proposed amendment to clause 5 and debate on clauses 1 to 20 and not the second reading stage speeches of the Attorney- General, the honourable member for Dobell or even the honourable member for North Sydney.

—I understand that; thank you, Mr Chairman. When one sees that this legislation contains 109 clauses of which we are now dealing with 20, it can be seen that it is a fairly complex Bill. However, as I have said before, there has been great delay. I point to only one other thing: The intercepts to which the Attorney-General referred and which I believe to be relevant to the point I am now making were done illegally and covertly. I see no reason to think that the New South Wales Government under Mr Neville Wran was told what was going on any more than the then Government under Mr Fraser was told what was going on. These were illegal intercepts mainly being carried out by the New South Wales Police Force, one member of which apparently sold them to the Commonwealth. Of course, the very fact that we learnt that illegal intercepts had taken place for such a long period only when Mr Justice Stewart conducted his inquiry gave greater impetus to the need for speed because, abuses on a wide scale having been discovered, it was then necessary for the Government to act-and act urgently. That most certainly has not been done. I will now formally move the amendment circulated in my name. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, page 3, lines 43 and 44, and page 4, lines 1-12, omit paragraph (a) of the definition of `class 2 offence', substitute the following paragraph:
`(a) an offence punishable by not less than 3 years imprisonment;'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to keep my comments as brief as possible. I oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). It seeks to allow telephone intercepts to be carried out by the police if the judge who signs the warrant believes that the relevant offence is such that the maximum penalty is at least three years. I believe that there are problems with that definition because there are some offences which have a maximum penalty of more than three years but which I do not believe warrant intercepting someone's telephone. Without wishing to go into a lot of detail, I think there is a danger that warrants could be issued by judges which would allow the police to intercept telephones for crimes which do not warrant telephones being intercepted.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people could argue: `Well, if someone is doing something wrong, no matter how trivial it is, why should this Parliament object to someone's telephone being intercepted to obtain evidence to prove in court that that person has done something which is against the law?' The simple reason why that statement is silly is that the police do not have the resources to carry out widespread telephone interceptions. Even if the honourable member for North Sydney's amendment is carried, the police would be limited, by the number of tape recorders and the number of trained expert staff available to the Australian Federal Police, to interceptions involving only very serious crimes such as murder, kidnapping and organised crime. Therefore, I oppose the amendment.

The honourable member dismissed the remarks that I made last night about the time involved in carrying out intercepts. I simply make the point that members of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception were shown around Telecom's central exchange in one of the capital cities, and also around the Australian Federal Police high security centre where the interceptions are carried out. Those who visited both locations were made aware that it was physically impossible for an intercept to be carried out within 30 seconds. Yes, it can be carried out quickly and at short notice, but I do not believe that it is proper for us to seek to alert criminals about the minimum time required. That would not serve a useful purpose. However, if a judge has granted a warrant by telephone, as is provided for in this legislation, Telecom and the Federal Police can ensure that an intercept is put in place in a short time. That could ensure that the police receive vital information.

The honourable member for North Sydney insists that the anti-terrorism group in New York has the capacity to intercept a telephone call in 30 seconds. I repeat that I do not believe that to be technically possible. It might be possible if someone had already hooked up a telephone intercept, as it might then take the police 30 seconds to turn on the tape recorder. However, to suggest that someone can route an intercept from the local exchange to the central headquarters-where the New York police carry out the intercepts-within 30 seconds is in the realms of fantasy. I shall certainly take up the honourable member's challenge to investigate his point. Perhaps the easiest way would be to write to the Federal Bureau of Investigation liaison officer at the American Embassy. I shall certainly follow that through, but I do not believe it to be technically possible for an intercept to be carried out in 30 seconds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to repeat a point that I made during last night's debate, namely, that this area was one of considerable conjecture among the members of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception. There was a wide range of views about the nature of the offences for which the facility of telephone tapping should be extended to aid in the detection of crime. Undoubtedly, the divisions essentially crossed political boundaries as we constructively worked together to try to find ways and means to address the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted in the debate yesterday that the Government had moved somewhat from the position determined by the majority group in the Committee. However, the minority group constructively suggested that there could be very good reason for greater flexibility in the way in which these matters are examined. The nature of criminal activity we might wish to investigate from time to time requires that those involved in its apprehension have the flexibility to move quickly. If the law limits the range of circumstances in which these facilities might be used, we might well find that in cases where evidence might otherwise be available it is simply not available to law enforcement agencies.

The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) has proposed an amendment that widens the class of offences that might be considered. In that context, I must mention that that does not mean that telephone taps can be used in every circumstance. There is the protection of having to go before a judicial officer to seek a warrant. That procedure in itself contains protection as considerable inquiry is undertaken. There are two purposes for moving these amendments. Before I refer to those purposes, I remind the Committee of the present state of the law in this country as to the use of intercept evidence which has been illegally obtained. The High Court of Australia, in the case of Hilton v. Wells, which was decided in 1985, decided by a majority of three to two that the Telecommunications (Interception) Act does not impliedly forbid the tender in evidence of information obtained in breach of its terms. The minority, the present Chief Justice and Mr Justice Deane, did not agree. In their view evidence could be given only on information obtained as a result of interception of a communication passing over a telecommunications system if that information was obtained by an authorised interception and if the proceedings in question were otherwise proceedings which fell within the Act. So we had two different views. On the one hand, we had the majority saying that there is no implied exclusion of evidence by virtue of the way in which the Act is presently structured and, on the other hand, the minority view that that evidence is to be rejected, that illegal evidence should not by this Act be admitted in court.

There is a case presently pending before the High Court of Australia which is to come on for hearing in one or two weeks but will not come on for hearing if clause 64 goes through, as I understand it from inquiries I have made. That case will be heard by a seven-member High Court, a full High Court, and effectively it will re-argue the decision in Hilton and Wells. That decision will be reopened so that the Court as a Full Bench can determine whether it should stand or whether the minority view should prevail. What is so important is that clause 64-this is the first of two points I want to raise-has the effect of making admissible, despite illegality, any evidence which has been obtained thus far in proceedings which have been commenced. Clause 64 states:
A person may:
(a) for a purpose connected with a proceeding begun before the commencement of this Part-
I miss out certain words-
(b) give in evidence in such a proceeding;
information:
(c) obtained by intercepting a communication before that commencement,-
that is, the commencement of this Part of the Bill-
whether or not in contravention of subsection 7 (1).

The effect of that is to reverse in advance or to prevent in advance the High Court's reconsidering the question because, if clause 64 goes through as it presently stands, it has these effects: In the first place, evidence illegally obtained in the past will be admissible for the purposes of proceedings begun before the commencement of this Bill, that is, admissible despite blatant illegality, and it will exclude any discretion in the Court to exclude evidence on the basis of illegality. It anticipates the High Court and effectively says to the Court: `We are not interested in your views on the Act of Parliament as it stands. We intend to make special rules which will allow illegal evidence to be used in existing proceedings regardless of the blatancy of the illegality'.

What this does is to move the law backwards to the law as it existed in England in 1955. There was a very famous case called Carooma. Carooma's case concerned a search which took place during the Mau-Mau emergency. The search was illegal. The Privy Council thought there were very grave doubts about the way in which the search had been carried out and about the evidence that had been given. But it was not reviewing the evidence; it was simply reviewing the law. The Privy Council came to a conclusion. It was put by Mr Justice Stefan and Mr Justice Akin in the case of Bunning v. Cross in these terms:

According to Carooma the discretion to be exercised when real evidence is sought to be tendered in a criminal trial is not different from, is indeed but an instance of that general discretion which always existed to exclude admissible evidence when to admit it would be unfair to the accused.

In other words, he simply looked at questions of prejudice. Our law has gone on a different path. We require public interest considerations to be examined and those public interest considerations are stated by Mr Justice Stefan and Mr Justice Aikin in Bunning v Cross. Effectively, what one does is to look at two competing requirements. I quote from what was said by them. Referring to an earlier case of Ireland, they said:

What Ireland involves is no simple question of assuring fairness to an accused but instead the weighing against each other of two competing requirements of public policy thereby seeking to resolve the apparent conflict between the desirable goal of bringing a conviction to the wrongdoer and the undesirable effect of curial approval or even encouragement being given to the unlawful conduct of those whose task it is to enforce the law.

We do not adopt the English law. But what this clause does effectively is to entrench an unjust view of inadmissibility for the purposes of proceedings that have already been commenced. I do not say this in any way critical of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) or of the Government, but surely the sensible thing is to leave to the High Court the decision of determining what is the proper interpretation of the existing Act so that, if evidence is admissible, even though it is obtained illegally, it is a matter for the Court to decide whether in exercising its discretion it should admit the evidence, or if the minority view prevails and there is an exclusion of any illegally obtained evidence, the Court should be left to decide that. Surely we should not as a Parliament be saying: `We are going to pass special rules here so that illegal evidence may be used regardless of what the High Court says as to the law that existed at the time that evidence was obtained'.

It is not simply the Opposition that objects to this. The Law Society of New South Wales has objected to it. I have heard from Mr Roger Gyles, the President of the Bar Association of New South Wales. This morning in the Press there was reference to an objection to it on behalf of the Law Council of Australia. We say that the law as it stands should apply to existing proceedings-that is, to evidence which has been obtained under the law as it stands-and that we should not change those rules. Furthermore, let us not make special rules for telephone interceptions prospectively. There is no distinction between the illegality of evidence obtained as a result of an illegal search and evidence obtained as a consequence of an illegal interception. In all cases it should be left to the courts to determine what in the balance of public interest is the right course to take in any particular case. As I said earlier, I understand that it is only in the case of telephone interceptions that we are to have special rules. For the life of me I can see no reason why we should have special rules applying to--

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF AIR MOVEMENTS CARGO HANGAR AT RAAF BASE, RICHMOND, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of air movements cargo hangar at RAAF Base, Richmond, New South Wales.

The proposed work that is now before the House, as I said, was referred to the Public Works Committee on 26 February 1987. It is for the construction of a new facility to house the cargo handling operations for the Royal Australian Air Force's air transport squadrons located at RAAF Base Richmond. Richmond is the home base for the RAAF's air transport force. It is the main distribution point for RAAF cargo destined for shipment within Australia and overseas. Cargo operations are currently carried out in an old aircraft hangar constructed in 1955. It is inadequate in size and functionally inappropriate for modern storage and handling techniques. Since air movements occupied the hangar in 1962 there has been a threefold increase in the amount of cargo handled. The number of air transport squadrons has also increased from one to four. This has led to substantial cargo operating inefficiencies in the confined hangar.

The proposed work will commence with the demolition of existing redundant facilities on the site, including a diesel generator, air traffic control masts and underground services. The new building will house receipt, dispatch, processing and storage areas, with associated administrative and staff facilities. Specialised equipment and racking to provide an automated pallet processing system will be installed. The work also includes the construction of an access road, parking areas and hardstand. The estimated cost of the work is $10.34m at February 1987 prices.

When the House referred this proposal to the Public Works Committee, I think the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) misunderstood some aspects of my speech. The honourable member considered that the cost of the work had increased and would continue to increase until construction was completed, based on an estimate from the explanations for estimates of expenditure for 1986-87. This estimate was $10.1m, but was in April 1986 prices as required for Budget purposes. As I have stated, the updated estimate of $10.34m is in February 1987 prices. This estimates not only reflects the effects of inflation since April 1986 but also involves a real reduction in the cost estimate through a reduction in the scope of the work. There is no requirement now to increase the scope of the work. Its final cost will reflect only inflationary pressures and not any real cost increases beyond the proposal's budget.

It is intended to call tenders in March 1988 for construction to commence in May 1988. The works should be completed by mid-1990. Consultants will be engaged to undertake the design of the facility. Actual construction is to be contracted to private enterprise in accordance with my Department's normal practice. The construction of the work will employ a work force ranging between 15 and 50. I would like to thank the Public Works Committee for the support it has given to this proposal. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the motion. This proposal has gone through the procedures of this Parliament, unlike those which were brought before the Parliament last week. On one occasion, a motion relating to the embassy in Japan was moved and in, fact, carried over the protests of the Opposition. No defence commitment was involved on that occasion. It was a question of the Government needing to sell some of its overseas property for the purpose of getting some cash in the bin so that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) could carry out his mini-Budget commitment which he told us was a matter of cutting expenditure, whereas it appears that the bulk of the savings will come from selling our assets, particularly those in Tokyo. While I would concern myself with cutting expenditure in some of our embassies and embassy property, in view of the importance of Japan to us in the area of trade and so on, I certainly would not consider our expenditures on the embassy in Japan or the property we hold in Japan a misplacement of Australian taxpayers' money. Nevertheless, that proposal was forced through this Parliament. Justice resides only in the numbers in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to see that the proposal before us has gone through the proper processes of this Parliament. I congratulate the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) on that. I am sure that had he had his way on the proposals which he brought before the Parliament last week they also would have gone through the proper processes with due consultation and investigation by the Joint Committee on Public Works, which I am sure you would agree, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a very important committee of this place. It is probably almost as important as one of the committees in which you are involved. It is a committee that is a watch-dog for the Australian people. It ensures that the people's rights are protected, because a huge amount of their taxes goes into projects of this nature. We know that the Committee has approved of this proposal. The Government has brought it to the Parliament in the proper fashion, the Parliament has sent it to the Committee and the Committee has reported favourably.

The proposal would appear to have merit because it will improve the capacity of the Royal Australian Air Force to deliver the goods-quite literally in this case, because storerooms and specialised equipment and racking to provide an automated pallet processing system will be installed. High technology is involved in terms of equipment and goods storage. Obviously the proposal will save the Government money in the future in terms of its costs and wages. Of course, the Government needs to save some money now on defence because part of its infamous mini-Budget was to cut $350m from the expenditure of the Department of Defence. The Government intends to make the cuts not in areas such as the one which the Minister brings before us today but in areas of recurrent expenditure-the operations side. The Government has told us quite clearly that there will be no cuts in capital works, such as this proposal, which means that it can continue to have its submarines built, of which it is so keen to make political capital. I guess that the Government will be able to conclude the purchase of the FA18s-the aircraft which we need to defend our country.

But the question that must be asked now is: How many people will there be to fly those aircraft and how many skilled submariners will there be to go in those wonderful new submarines, as a result of the pressure that the Government is putting on the personnel within the organisation of our defence establishment? The proposal obviously will make life better for personnel in the defence establishment because it will give them better working conditions and a mechanisation which will reduce the load that they would otherwise have to bear. I hope that the proposal is not an indication that the Government will approve of the rather foolish arrangement of limiting the amount which people may lift to 16 kilograms. That was a recommendation of one of the quangos which the Government created at a cost, as I recall, of about $40m a year and which the Opposition opposed at the time-that is, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. We felt that the State governments had plenty of money to spend on such things.

The Commission's first recommendation to us which would be applicable in the proposed storerooms is that no human being should lift an item weighing more than 16 kilograms. The weight limit of a bag which people can carry on aircraft on an interstate or international flight happens to be 16 kilograms. I have seen slips of girls arguing like steam with people behind the check-in counters because their bag is about 10 kilograms over the permitted weight and they are trying not to pay excess baggage. Those girls are able to throw their bags on to the check-in scales with no trouble at all. Yet, a Government department says that no strong man should do such a thing. The proposal talks of inflationary pressures. I think that we must query that. The Opposition does not oppose the proposal. It wishes the Minister well and hopes that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will come up with some new ideas to contain inflation so that the cost does not blow out too much.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS BILL 1987[COGNATE BILLS:INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER BILL 1987INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 May, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill. As there is no objection, the Chair will allow this course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill basically arise because of the action by the trade union movement dating back to September 1985. Later I will explain what the history of the matter is. Since then, the Government has been issuing Press releases on the standards to be applied to the conduct of superannuation funds. People have had to try to make decisions on the basis of those Press releases and without the benefit of legislation. This has been a practice of this Government. It introduced a wide range of tax measures in a mere statement in September 1985, and it took months and months for the legislation to come through. People were not able to order their affairs on the basis of any legislation. The same thing has happened with the media; statements were made about new rules of media ownership and people risked enormous sums of money without the basis of legislation and, in that case, took great risks.

SPEECH.PARA: In this case, all those whose job it is to carry out in an orderly fashion the conduct of superannuation funds have been relying for months and months-in fact, since the Government put out a Press release in December 1985-on a series of Press releases in order to make satisfactory judgments on people's assets for their retirements. We are now running into the last few weeks before an election. This legislation will not be dealt with by the Senate during this sitting because it was not introduced into the Senate by 1 June. The Government must be sorely embarrassed by the fact that the industry, which has been screaming for some sort of legislative base for its activities, will, once again, be disappointed by the headlong rush of this Government into a premature election. That is why the House of Representatives is now looking at this Bill. It obviously will not be passed by the Parliament before it is dissolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your assistance, I think we can get it through.

—The Minister at the table says it can get through with my assistance. The problem is that the Senate is absolutely jam packed with legislation. Senators are being asked to debate quite important legislation within a matter of two or three hours at the most for each Bill. They have expressed their extreme concern about this, and it is unlikely that they will accept this legislation, however much we would like the framework to be in place. That is the problem of the Government; it is responsible for the delay in bringing this Bill before the House. It has had a long time to do so. Since its original statement in December 1985, the Government has had 18 months or more to bring down this legislation and now, at the last gasp, it is brought before the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The first set of changes the package of Bills brings about is the appointment and setting up of an office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. This is a new body. There is an abolition of the current statutory positions of the Insurance Commissioner and the Life Insurance Commissioner. Earlier, it was foreshadowed that an Office of Occupational Superannuation Commissioner be set up separately, but that proposal has been dropped. The two insurance commissioners and the Government actuary will be included in the new office. The Opposition has no quarrel with bringing them all into the one office and the one statutory area. It seems to be a sensible rationalisation, except that I draw the attention of the Minister for Community Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) to the added costs that have been incurred in doing this. An interesting letter appeared in the Australian Financial Review of Monday, 1 June from Mr Ray Stevens, Director, Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight of Melbourne. I will read the letter because it makes a very important argument:
Sir, When a bill is introduced into Parliament these days, it must be accompanied by a statement on the costs involved in implementing the proposal set out in the bill.

This requirement has the commendable objective of assisting the Parliament to decide whether the costs involved in implementing and maintaining the proposals submitted are justified by the bill's objectives.
On May 14, 1987 the introduction of three bills relating to insurance and superannuation demonstrated that the Public Service treats these requirements as a joke.
Two of the bills relate to establishment of the new office of insurance and superannuation commissioner.

Under this commissioner there will be three deputy commissioners, each with his own department. Two of these departments already exist, operating as the offices of the Insurance Commissioner and the Life Insurance Commissioner (Occupational Superannuation).

An interim group established a year ago in anticipation of Parliament's approval of the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner's office has grown like wildfire. Some of its functions were intended to replace existing Tax Department activities.

Avoidance of duplication has not, however, worked in practice. For example, new trust deeds and trust deed amendments must now be sent to both the Tax Department and the Interim Group, instead of just the Tax Department, with each requiring completion of a different questionnaire.
In spite of this the bills presented to Parliament contain a financial impact statement claiming that the only additional expenditure will be the remuneration to be paid to the new commissioner.
``The integration of insurance, superannuation and actuarial functions should improve efficiency and provide savings.''
Mr Stevens was then quoting from the Minister's second reading speech. The letter continued:
With two existing departments continuing as at present, and a third new department being added, this claim shows the public servants are treating the requirements of Parliament as a joke.
However, the statement which really takes the cake appears in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill.

Under this bill it is proposed that a fee be paid by each superannuation fund to recover the costs of administering the supervisory requirements. ``it is therefore anticipated that generally there will be no net cost to the Commonwealth,'' says the financial impact statement.

In other words, if the cost of a new government department can be directly passed on to the community, the Parliament can ignore the cost when deciding whether the expanded public service is justified!

An initial levy of $30 a fund, estimated to raise $6 million a year, is proposed under this third bill-to cover costs which the statements presented with two of the three bills suggest will be covered by improved efficiency.

It seems unlikely that any of the variety of Opposition groups will question the need for this legislation. It just goes to show you can fool some of the people some of the time, but the only people you can fool all of the time are Federal members of Parliament.

I inform Mr Ray Stevens that the Opposition is taking up this matter and it considers his arguments to be of some force, perhaps greater than he might think. In January, the Minister for Community Services and Minister assisting the Treasurer wrote to the life insurance industry suggesting that not only should there be an initial $30 a fund levy but also another levy on the industry to cover the cost of regulation. The Minister suggested that this would happen and he sought the views of the industry. The industry objected very strongly to that, calling a supervisory levy an unprecedented, selective and discriminatory tax. It was envisaged that the cost of a levy might be a couple of million dollars. Does this mean that every time some regulatory requirement on an industry is set up, a tax or charge on that industry is made to cover the cost of the regulatory body so that we can say to the Parliament, as pointed out by Mr Stevens, that it is not really costing anything or the financial impact of this is nil, because an additional cost is actually being imposed on an industry. The additional cost might not be borne directly by the taxpayer, but that is not very useful. The cost is obviously passed to the consumers through the higher charges that must be paid for the administration and so on of these funds. My colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) will be moving a couple of amendments relating to the office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The Liberal Party will be supporting those amendments. I will leave it to the honourable member for Richmond to describe his amendments.

In the relatively limited time I have available let me go to the substance of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. This is an important issue. The background of this is that on 4 September 1985 the Government came to an agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions under the accord mark 2 whereby the unions were to obtain for their members through the conciliation and arbitration system a 3 per cent disguised wage increase, called a productivity increase, which would be in the form of superannuation contributions by employers on behalf of employees. This was a deal stitched up between the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the ACTU to disguise a wage increase which was over and above what was economically justified. It was necessary for the Treasurer to present a front to the financial community to try to say that the wage increase that was being granted, which was clearly in advance of wage increases being granted by our competitors overseas, was somehow not a wage increase. So it was called a productivity increase and it was to be paid in the form of superannuation. The ACTU pulled an old policy objective out of the drawer in order to accommodate the Treasurer on that point. On 16 December 1985, before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission had made any decision, the Government published guidelines and draft operating standards for occupational superannuation funds.

On 11 June 1986, some six months later, the Government published comprehensive standards for these funds to meet the requirements of the Australian Taxation Office so that the funds would enjoy the tax concessions that are available to superannuation funds. Unfortunately for the Government, on 26 June 1986, shortly after these comprehensive standards had been issued, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission came out with a rather confused decision, a typical political fudge of that body, in which it said that it was not prepared to agree that everybody would get this 3 per cent so-called productivity increase but that it would only confirm consent arrangements between employers and unions. That meant, of course, that the more powerful unions would be able to force employers into putting money into union- controlled superannuation funds. On 30 July 1986 the Government, obviously a little concerned by this CAC refusal absolutely to toe the line, issued a further statement promising consultation with the industry.

On 10 March 1987 the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, seeing the chaos that was reigning in this area because unions were bullying employers into various schemes, modified its decision and said that rather than rely on consent arrangements it would arbitrate in any particular dispute, thereby putting itself in the position to force this so-called productivity increase on the whole of the employed work force. That is the history of it. It started with a fraudulent deal between the Treasurer and the ACTU in order to disguise a wage increase. It has led to the Government scrambling along the way to try to catch up with what the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission was deciding and what the unions were pushing for in the field. The standards, in effect, have been operative from 1 July 1986 and here at last, in the dying days of the Parliament, we have some legislation which cannot get through the Senate, but we still do not have the regulations which are the real operating standards. So this Bill, on operating standards, merely sets up a framework for regulations which, of course, are subject to disallowance under the Acts Interpretation Act. We will certainly be looking very closely at those regulations when they come in to see whether we like them.

We have expressed in the past our reservations about certain aspects of the standards, particularly about the preservation of benefits to age 55 and not to age 65. We will not oppose this main aspect of the Bill, but we certainly would like to have a look at the precise standards when we see the regulations. Now that they will not go through the Parliament we expect to be setting up the new regulations in government. For the record, it seems a little futile to go ahead now, given that the whole legislation will be under our control in a very short time. Nonetheless, I will proceed at the Committee stage to move two amendments. The first amendment is to clause 3, page 3. At the end of the definition of `superannuation fund', we want to add:
but does not include:
(c) a fund established as a result of an employer or employers being threatened, intimidated or coerced by a trade union or trade unions.

In other words, for the superannuation funds to enjoy the taxation concessions that are available we would want to be certain that funds were not set up as a result of coercion. That taxation concessions would not be available to a fund if an employer who has to pay money on behalf of the employee into a fund does not agree to put the money into that fund, or if the money is put into a fund because of pressure and without the agreement of the employer, of if employees did not agree that their long term retirement money was to go into a particular fund. As far as we are concerned, that is an elementary matter of civil liberties and rights, and it is linked with our approach to industrial relations, to non-compulsory unionism. Funds such as the building unions superannuation scheme fund which have been set up as a result of coercion of employers by unions would have to be examined very closely and would be excluded from the taxation concessions if it were found that they were set up as a result of coercion.
The second amendment will be to clause 7, page 6, sub-clause (2), after paragraph (j). We propose that the following paragraph be inserted:
(ja) the levels of administrative fees, commissions or other deductions which may be payable from amounts contributed to superannuation funds;

Here we would want to regulate these fees to ensure that money was not siphoned off by unions and used for their own purposes instead of for the genuine administration of funds by the fund managers. We believe that a very close look has to be taken at where this money is going and how it is being used-money that employees, as a matter of free choice, would rather go into a fund organised by some body other than a union, or money that employers, as a matter of free choice, would rather went into a fund other than one governed by a union. It is not a very happy thought for somebody who is looking at his or her retirement nest egg to be under the control of unions such as those in the building industry that are responsible for the BUS scheme. One does not get much of a squeal from the industry on these things because the industry likes to manage these funds. As these funds build up, the most reputable of companies become involved in the management of the funds. But the source of the funds is tainted in many cases, because they are there as a result of intimidation and, in the case of the building unions, very much by intimidation.

If I had more time I would give the House a number of examples of where people have been bludgeoned on building sites and elsewhere into becoming members of these funds, of where subcontractors have been forced into these funds with employees, and where they have no choice if they are to continue to work on building sites. There are other industries where this is happening. It simply cannot be allowed to continue. Under a Liberal government it certainly will not be allowed to continue. Therefore, within the very near future we will take steps in office to prevent this kind of coercion occurring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill now before the House give effect to the announcements of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 11 June, 30 July and 22 December last year. On those occasions he announced various operating standards which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds would be required to meet to be eligible for relevant taxation concessions. The most important of the three Bills we are considering tonight is the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, but I will deal first with the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill, which is designed to create the position of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and thereby establish an Insurance and Superannuation Commission in Australia. Certainly, as far as the superannuation industry is concerned, this is undoubtedly the most important legislation to come before Parliament in a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing statutory office holders fully support and have encouraged the Government to adopt this change in approach. There has been a change on earlier recommendations considered by the Government to establish new full commissioner positions for the administration and control of these industries, and the Government has now decided to establish one overall commissioner and a number of deputy commissioners in each of the specialist areas. The first result of this will be greater integration of the various superannuation insurance functions; and the second is that the difficulties in achieving that objective which could arise from maintaining a number of specific statutory offices will be overcome to a very large extent.

The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill provides that where the trustees of a superannuation fund or an approved deposit fund provide to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner certain information on the operations of the fund, together with certificates as prescribed, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will notify the trustees of the fund whether the Commission itself is satisfied that the fund has met the relevant standards and requirements for the purpose of establishing eligibility for concessional taxation treatment. That is a fundamental question about this legislation because we know that successive governments over many years have taken advantage of the opportunity to provide in various ways taxation concessions which have been designed to encourage people, in effect, to provide for their own retirement income.

This Government has taken a number of initiatives in connection with the operation of superannuation schemes and the way in which those schemes would effectively provide an income flow for people in their retirement. Of course, the most recent was an extremely important provision undertaken by this Government to tax the lump sum benefits of superannuitants in order to encourage them to take out those benefits in the form of an income flow because the taxation concessions provided by the Government had been intended to encourage them to do that. Of course, to a very large extent that objective was being frustrated because, contrary to the purpose of creating an income flow by having these people provide for their own retirement income, people were taking advantage of the accrued benefit which existed within the superannuation funds for them and taking it out in the form of a lump sum benefit. So, in effect, we were providing very extensive taxation benefits to make it possible for people when they retired to upgrade the standard of their homes, buy a new motor vehicle, a weekender or a launch or take a trip overseas. All of those things are quite commendable in themselves but they are certainly not the purpose for which those taxation concessions and arrangements were provided. So now we are encouraging the use of superannuation benefits and entitlements for the purposes for which they were originally intended.

The other part, in addition to the creation of the Commission, is the creation of certain standards, as I have indicated, that will guarantee that superannuation funds qualify for the taxation concessions which are available. They will be required to satisfy conditions in a number of different areas. First, standards are created for improvement in the vesting provisions of superannuation; that is, the extent to which particularly employers' contributions towards the funds will be retained by employees for the benefit of employees.

Secondly, there are improved requirements governing the extent to which the interest of the employee will be preserved in the accumulating benefit within the fund. There are improved portability arrangements so that when employees who have contributed to superannuation funds and have in turn had their employers contribute on their behalf move from one occupation to another their accrued benefit within the fund is portable and can move with them.

Thirdly, there are measures to ensure greater member involvement in the control of superannuation funds and, despite many quite spurious and in some cases malicious accusations and claims that have been peddled by members of the Opposition about the total operation of these new arrangements and the extent to which unions may or may not be in a position to control what will undoubtedly prove in the future to be very substantial sums of money, the Government is now providing, in the arrangements which it is now introducing, for equal representation by the employers and employees. Why should that not be so? Both groups contribute and both have an interest in the effectiveness with which those funds operate; and both are entitled to have some say as to the extent to which and the way in which the funds are controlled. But if there was any concern about the way in which the funds would be directed and the way in which they would be utilised, that concern is also overcome by the fact that these provisions not only ensure improved security for members' benefits but also ensure that the direction of those funds and their investment will be determined on the basis of commercial considerations.

We have heard some nonsense from members of the Opposition. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) suggested that one of his amendments is directed towards ensuring that money is not siphoned off to the trade unions. That is an absurd proposition. It is offensive not only to trade unions and to employees who themselves are involved in and contribute towards these funds but also to the capacity of employer representatives, who will have at least 50 per cent of the controlling interest over those funds and the direction of their investment. If the best that the Opposition can do in relation to legislation of this kind is to come up with quite ridiculous, unnecessary and offensive amendments, it really needs to re-examine its position on these questions.

Apart from some members of the Opposition, no one denies that these Bills take into account recent consultations between the Government and industry representatives. Those consultations on the regulations are continuing even at this stage, and they will continue into the future. If there are any blemishes, they will show themselves and undoubtedly the Government has sufficient interest to ensure that any residual difficulties or blemishes that may exist are hauled out of the system so that it can operate as intended. Of course, the Commission will better reflect the growing importance of the insurance and superannuation industries to the national economy. Some people, particularly people in private funds and private arrangements, may have felt threatened about the future of the section 23fb funds. They are the private funds which provide for their contributors, for the people who participate, the benefit of up to $1,500 in taxation deductions each year, depending on the value of the contribution that they make.

The Government has made it perfectly clear that it sees a continued and important role for those section 23fb funds both as vehicles for portability of superannuation benefits and as one of the types of funds eligible for the receipt of productivity payments if agreed between the relevant parties. The Government has also made it perfectly clear that it wants to allay the concerns expressed in some of the submissions on the earlier published draft standards with respect to the continued availability of the $1,500 taxation deduction for unsupported personal contributions to those funds. It is possible that, in future, we may need to re-examine that limit. It is important that a limit exists, but substantial benefits accrue to the public sector by encouraging individuals to make their own arrangements for retirement income.
Madam Deputy Speaker, there is general recognition that, despite--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is Madam Speaker; I keep being demoted.

—I am sorry, Madam Speaker. There is continuing recognition that the taxation benefits available to encourage people to participate in superannuation funds are substantial, and that is still the case despite the fact that, recently, provision has been made for an adjustment in the way in which lump sum benefits are taxed. Undoubtedly, superannuation is one of the most tax effective investments available, and should be near the top of every investor's list of options. Yet, despite the potential benefits for some people, the decision to join a superannuation scheme can turn out to be a costly mistake. Too often people, especially those in the non-public sector major superannuation funds, make inadequate preparation and inquiries into the details and circumstances of the funds that they eventually enter. Some of the operators of those funds have a lot to answer for in that regard. In many respects, the existing provisions are confusing, so people need to obtain expert advice.
