In addition, some place far too much emphasis on the commission that can accrue to the salesman in the field flogging the schemes. Naturally enough, his chief purpose is to sell the schemes that provide the greatest commission. There is a great deal of confusion, and many unnecessary mistakes are made when people enter schemes. They are certainly matters to which consideration should be given.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983, a survey was conducted among employees seeking advice about the considerations in their employment that they thought to be the more important. One especially interesting result was that 84 per cent of the work force considered superannuation to be the most important benefit that an employer could offer. The revenue that is forgone at the Commonwealth level because of the taxation concessions which successive governments have accepted in order to encourage people to participate in superannuation schemes amounts to about $3,000m every year. That has encouraged some people to suggest that because only about 50 per cent of the total work force contribute to superannuation funds, and as the total work force consists of about six million people, three million people are taking advantage of the $3,000m a year taxation benefits that are designed to encourage them to participate in the funds. That works out at a benefit per participant of about $1,000 a year. It may be that $3,000m appears to be substantial, but an individual benefit averaging $1,000 a year ceases to be quite so significant, especially if we take account of the ultimate benefit not only to the participant in providing for a flow of retirement income in excess of the flow of income that he could expect to obtain from an old age pension, but also to the public sector because of the reduced burden on it of providing additional retirement incomes. Although concerns are expressed from time to time about the imposition on government revenue and government fiscal policy of the taxation benefits for superannuation funds, in the long run it is generally accepted that the benefits are appropriate and should be kept in place.

There is one matter to which I wish to draw particular attention in the time left to me. The Government's position on superannuation and the operation of the funds has been made perfectly clear. Our approach towards superannuation funds, the standards applied, the conditions related to the direction of those funds and the appropriate forms of taxation concessions that should relate to them, has probably been the most comprehensive and fruitful of any government-and to a much greater and better extent.

I am concerned that a threat has been made against the superannuation funds. The Opposition has indicated that their investment income is likely to be taxed. Such a policy has been resisted for a long time. The superannuation funds themselves are concerned about the implications of such a policy, and the operators of the private funds that make special provision for individual employees who are not covered by other types of superannuation arrangements have felt threatened. Now, it appears that they have good cause.

We know that there is a $16,000m credibility gap between the undertakings given by the Opposition and its capacity to raise funds to finance those undertakings. Of course, that $16,000m must be financed in some way. I ask the Opposition whether the threat to tax the investment income of superannuation funds is part of the hidden agenda to help to finance that $16,000m credibility gap. I think it likely that it is. As I have said, $3,000m of that credibility gap between the Opposition's commitments and its capacity to finance them could be eliminated in one fell swoop by removing the $3,000m taxation concession. Those 50 per cent of employees-wage and salary earners throughout the whole Australia-who now have superannuation benefits need to take on board very seriously the possibility that the investment income of those superannuation funds would be taxed if the two parties on the Opposition benches were ever to come to government.

There was an article on superannuation in the Sydney Morning Herald today, showing the contrast when a person with, say, a $10,000 a year salary increase chooses to save it in the normal way or to invest it in superannuation. The difference, as a result of the taxation concessions, is this: The benefit to the person who saves in the normal way and is taxed at a marginal rate of 40c in the dollar after 30 years would be about $790,000. But if the $10,000 a year is put into superannuation, with all the taxation benefits that result from that, the figure is about $2.5m. So those people who have taken out superannuation should make sure that their interests are not ripped off them by a political party that would tax their benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is normally a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). He is one of the few members on the Government benches who have an understanding of economics. Tonight, I suppose, given a very difficult subject, he did his best to defend a fairly ragtag policy. The only thing I would deplore about his comments tonight was that the last few minutes of his remarks degenerated into a bit of cheap political point scoring about an issue which he knows is pure speculation. It really does not do credit to his reputation either as an economist or as a debater in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: One point that the honourable member for Charlton made is worth restating-that is, that superannuation is very important to all people in Australia. It is also very important to a government in planning fiscal policy for the future. The demographic studies of the Australian population indicate that from about 2010 we will have a very large retired population. At that point the cost of financing retirement income for those people will be very high if it devolves completely on the public sector. It is for that reason that we must act now, and we must act decisively now, to ensure that we have an adequate superannuation policy in this country to allow people to plan for their retirement years. It takes 25 to 35 years to provide for one's retirement. Over a working lifetime, unless one starts fairly early to plan for retirement, the benefit that will be available will be inadequate to maintain the standard of living to which most people aspire or have become accustomed to during their working lives.

The honourable member for Charlton made reference to the legislation that we are debating tonight. It is a cognate debate involving three pieces of legislation that have bearing on superannuation, retirement income and insurance-the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. He also made reference to the fact that the legislation enacts statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in June, July and December 1986. I wonder how much priority the Government attaches to superannuation when since June 1986 we have had planning for people's retirement, which takes 35 years, based on a Press release. That is the sort of priority that the Government has. It issues Press releases because it has been pushed into a corner by the demands of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which has its own motives in the superannuation debate. In the dying hours of this Parliament, just before this Government is defeated, legislation is introduced which the honourable member for Charlton knows will lapse because it will not be introduced in the Senate this week before Parliament is prorogued. I guess the honourable member did a sterling job. He debated with some enthusiasm the significance of this legislation, knowing full well that it will lapse. It will have to be brought back in the new Parliament by a new government and it will reflect a new philosophy on superannuation.

As I said, superannuation is very important. For that reason it is very important that the guidelines and framework established by a government for superannuation planning are first class; that they are equitable and fair; and that people who are putting a fairly sizable proportion of their weekly or monthly earnings into a superannuation plan can count on the Government's policy in that area. Since June last year we have had policy by Press release-much akin to the Government's policy on media amalgamation. Some people invested hundreds of millions of dollars in the area of media amalgamation on the basis of a Press release. Not everybody is in the category of people who are buying television networks. Some people have a far more modest approach to saving and planning for their retirement. They are the sort of people who are putting 3 per cent of their weekly earnings into superannuation funds. That is the figure that the Government has agreed with the ACTU. What the Government has not told people who are putting that money aside is that 3 per cent is totally inadequate to provide a reasonable superannuation payout in order to sustain a reason- able standard of living on their retirement.

The honourable member for Charlton made comments about the need to ensure that superannuation is preserved to provide retirement income. What he did not mention was that the preservation provisions of the Government's deal with the ACTU refer to age 55. At 55 a person can get superannuation. He could probably spend the fairly modest amount that 3 per cent will accumulate for him in the five years between ages 55 and 60. He will then have a need for further support and the burden, unless something is done about this Government's superannuation policy, will come back to the public sector. For the `public sector', read the `Australian taxpayer of the day'. As I said previously, in about 2010 the burden of financing retirement income in this country will be considerably more than it is at present.

There are a number of problems with the legislation that is before us tonight. If one listened to Government speakers, one would believe that there was absolutely nothing wrong with it and that it was the subject of unanimous support from the entire industry. That is not the case. On Friday, 29 May, in the Melbourne Herald there was an article about superannuation which referred to the legislation that we are currently debating. It states:

. . . the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner . . . who will have the power of administering the new and complex rules on superannuation. That section will cost an extra $6 million-which will be paid for by a $30 levy on each superannuation fund to cover the estimated costs.

But the Government has not done any estimate of the cost of the extra facilities and administration that will arise from the provisions of this legislation, should it go through this Parliament. The article continues:
. . . the superannuation industry believes that there could be another 300 public servants . . . in addition to the 200 now employed in the area.

So there are 200 at present and another 300 will have to be hired. It is almost like the fringe benefits tax or the assets test. The Government seems to be quite confused about how it will actually administer this question of superannuation. In fact, leading actuaries Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight Pty Ltd have stated that the method that the Government has chosen will become almost impossible to administer within a few years. In its opinion it will have to be replaced. The actuaries' argument only concerns the method. They, like every member on this side, have no argument with the need to have effective guidelines for superannuation and to ensure that the principal of preserving benefits is adhered to.

The Institute of Actuaries has put forward an alternative approach which it thinks the Government should consider. This involves dropping some of the calculations which are enshrined in this legislation in adopting a totally different approach. I mention that point because it is very important for those people who are listening. A large proportion of those people who are listening to the broadcast of this debate tonight would be participants in superannuation schemes. It is their future, their savings and their retirement standards of living that we are talking about in this legislation.

There are a number of aspects of this legislation that are of concern to us. I mentioned that the Government is pretending that everybody agrees with its approach to it. It has certainly not achieved the unanimous agreement of all people who have an interest in the industry. The Life Underwriters Association has constantly corresponded with just about everybody in the Government that it can think of to try to put its point of view on this very important subject. It has written to the Commissioner of Taxation, the Treasurer and the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), who I see is in the chamber tonight. It has not received a response from anybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—The Minister says that that is not true. That is the information that has been given to me. I am quite sure that if it has received a response, it will communicate that to me. It raised a number of very important issues in that correspondence which should be laid before the public. One of those is the situation where overfunding occurs. That will be a more frequent occurrence as a result of the deal that the Australian Labor Party has done with the ACTU on superannuation. Many people in Australia have-or had prior to the Simon Crean, Gary Weaven, Bill Kelty deal, on superannuation-their own private superannuation plans, either in conjunction with an employer or privately through a superannuation fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Under our taxation arrangements there is a limit on contributions and benefits that can be made to these funds. Overfunding arises when, as a result of this new deal-it is about 3 per cent-a person gets a pay-in and a pay-out which is above the limits that have currently been established. The Life Underwriters Association wrote to the Commissioner of Taxation on 25 March and raised this very important issue. It stated in part:
To adequately advise our members and their clients, the LUA would appreciate your advice on the following:
1. When overfunding occurs will tax concessions be lost to the `union sponsored fund' as the cause of the overfunding-
because that is the most recent fund-
or to the other fund(s) involved, or both'?

As I have said, it is my understanding that there has been no answer to that very important question. Secondly, it raised the question of what action can be taken by a taxpayer who is already funding the maximum benefits but who is coerced into joining a union sponsored fund. Members of the Australian Labor Party will say that there is no coercion. But let me tell them that one has only to drive around our community and look at some of the stickers that the Transport Workers Union of Australia and other trade unions are using to promote their superannuation funds to see that there is coercion and that people will not be allowed on to certain sites or into certain jobs unless they are members of a union sponsored superannuation fund, notwithstanding the fact that they may have already contributed to the maximum to some other private or employer sponsored fund. This is a very important issue and we still have no answer from the Government.

The third question put was: Can employers pay superannuation contributions for self-employed contractors? The fourth question was: If coercion can be proved, are the trustees of a trade union sponsored fund in breach of their duties as trustees if a taxpayer is forced to join a trade union sponsored fund and in so doing that taxpayer is overfunded? Those four questions should be answered by this Government because they are very important. They are important not only to the general determination of superannuation policy; they are very important to the tax status and to the retirement planning status of those people who are making contributions to those funds. That is just one example of some of the very complex issues in this whole superannuation question which have been inadequately dealt with by this Government.

One classic example of the Government's inadequacy in this area is its determination to move ahead to ensure that future regulations for superannuation funds and what are known as approved deposit funds will be established by regulation, not legislation. Let me say that we in the National Party of Australia believe that something that is so important to many millions of Australians, something that takes 35 years to put in place, something that determines whether one's efforts over a working life will be successful during one's retirement-whether one is to have a happy and content retirement or whether one will be reduced to penury-should not be able to be changed at the whim of regulation. If it takes a long time to plan for one's retirement, it should take a substantial effort for a government of the day to change the rules affecting a superannuation fund or an approved deposit fund. We do not believe it is appropriate for people's life savings-that is what we are talking about in superannuation and approved deposit funds-to be changed by regulation. If the changes or the guidelines that the Government proposes from time to time for superannuation funds and ADFs are so significant to individuals, surely this Government and any government should be prepared to come back into the Parliament and put the legislation to a debate-not simply to make the changes by way of regulation, by delegated legislation. That is totally unacceptable.

I should add that we are concerned at some of the administrative procedures that the Government envisages. We believe that the proposed term of seven years for the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner is too long. We suggest that five years would be more than adequate to attract a person of the necessary calibre. We recognise that it is an important statutory office but we are concerned that from time to time there may be a tendency by governments to make political appointments. Seven years represents two and a bit terms of this Parliament; that is a long time. We believe that five years is a far more appropriate term of office. It is still sufficient for a person of sufficient calibre to administer the office adequately and make sure that policy is implemented and administration effective. Seven years is too long.

We are also concerned at some of the bureaucratic approaches and the excuses for inactivity that have been slipped into this legislation. In the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill there is a proposal that, where the Commission finds that a fund does not meet a particular guideline, there is a right of appeal. The appeal has to be made within 21 days of the ruling. Currently, following lodgment of one's tax return with the Australian Taxation Office, one has 60 days in which to appeal. The provision of 21 days is a reduction. We do not think that is on. Superannuation is complex and there is a need to consult trustees, change deeds, et cetera. But the 21-day reduction is not the most significant provision.

The most significant provision is that if after that appeal is lodged the Commission does not take a decision within 21 days, it is deemed that the original determination is upheld. What an excuse for bureaucratic inaction! If one puts in an appeal and nothing is done about it, the original decision is confirmed. That is just a Claytons appeal procedure. We will formally move an amendment at the Committee stage. As I have said, this Bill will lapse because the Parliament will be prorogued on Friday--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not if we have your support. We can get it through. We will listen to your amendments.

—If the Government accepts our amendments, we will be more than happy. But fancy giving bureaucrats an excuse not to do anything. What sort of government would bring in that sort of provision to the Parliament and say: `You have 21 days. If you do nothing in those 21 days, we will let you off the hook'? Then the trustees of the superannuation fund would have to go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Heaven only knows what the backlog in the AAT is at this time since we have abolished the taxation boards of review and every tax appeal now goes to the AAT at the princely cost of $200. We think that is fundamentally wrong. It is not the right approach to superannuation. But it is the same sort of approach that allows this Government to cave in to the demands of the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a lot of rhetoric come from the Government benches about how the Government is really concerned to address the retirement income funding problem, how it is really concerned to provide adequate superannuation for the people of Australia, the workers of Australia, and to extend the coverage of superannuation right throughout the community. Let me say that I have no argument with any of those objectives. They are laudable objectives and they are supported by every member of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Liberal Party.

—And they are supported by the Liberal Party of Australia. What we are absolutely concerned about is that in doing this the Government is handing to the trade union movement, just as it did with the industrial relations legislation which was withdrawn earlier this week, another club with which to belt the Australian community about the ears. The Government has said that 50 per cent of the trustees will represent workers. But unfortunately, in this Government's dictionary, workers are members of trade unions. That is not true. At present less than 50 per cent of workers are members of trade unions. What we should have is a bit of genuine industrial democracy, which is not government by the ACTU of the ACTU for the ACTU. What it is really about is providing the people who put their money into those funds with some say in the way in which that money is managed. Of course, the obligations of a trustee are to manage the funds to maximise the return for the trustees.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not so long ago that we saw in the popular Press throughout Australia calls by trade union leaders to pull money out of certain investments and put it into other selected causes. That was for political reasons, either that they did not like the South African regime which was repugnant, or that they felt that there was not enough activity in the housing industry and that there was an absolute need to put more money into the housing industry, or that they thought they should be funding some sort of fantasy theme land out in the western suburbs of Sydney. All of those decisions are decisions taken on a whim or a fancy or for political reasons-not because they maximise the return on the funds or because they maximise the returns for the people paying into these funds, but because they give the trade unions who are putting those trustees on those funds more leverage, more industrial muscle and more clout within the industrial system and the Australian economy.

a Can honourable members imagine a situation in which the ACTU had control of the majority of superannuation funds throughout Australia? The whim of Simon Crean, Bill Kelty or anyone who happens to succeed them would determine the investment decisions on billions of dollars in this community-not a rational basis to maximise return, not on a basis that would ensure that the Australian economy had an adequate supply of funds into those areas of our community that need to be developed because the market says: `That is the optimum place for us to grow and that will increase the standard of living of all Australians, make sure that our gross domestic product grows at a competitive rate with the rest of the world, make sure that our industries are competitive and make sure that we can export'. Heaven only knows where Treasurer Keating's J-curve would be if it were up to the ACTU to decide the investment priorities of some of the major superannuation funds. The investments would not go anywhere near the industries that his Government would prefer. They would go on politically popular causes.

What we must have in this country is fair dinkum superannuation-superannuation that does not have Simon Crean and Bill Kelty with their fingers in the pie; superannuation that gives genuine representation to the people who are contributing to the funds; superannuation that provides an adequate pay-out at the end of a working life-not some Clayton's superannuation that provides an inadequate pay-out at 55 and that does not address the public policy issue of funding retirement income in the year 2010.

This Government's policy is totally inadequate. It does not know where it is going. That is why in this legislation we have the statement in clauses 7 and 8 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill that guidelines will be determined by regulation. The reason they are not being determined by legislation is that the Government does not know where it is going. Press releases were rushed out in June and July of 1986. At this point the Government still does not have a legislative framework for superannuation guidelines in Australia. That is how well thought out its superannuation policy is, and it underlines again that we are in the mess we are in now because Simon Crean and Bill Kelty call the shots for this Government. They call the shots for superannuation, they call the shots for taxation and they call the shots for industrial legislation. They are even determining this Government's foreign policy. It is not good enough for the many millions of people in Australia who are relying on a responsible government to provide decent guidelines for their retirement income planning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The exercise by the Government in bringing forward the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill, in my view, is nothing more than an exercise in futility. I say that because all of us in this chamber know full well that even if these Bills are passed by this House they will not go forward to the Senate. This package of Bills cannot be passed into legislation.
—Why?

—It cannot become law because this Parliament will be dissolved before this legislation becomes law. If the purpose of the exercise is not to put legislation and laws on the statute book, what is the intention of the Government in bringing it forward? I believe, as I believe does the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), that the purpose of the Government in bringing this legislation forward is to prove its bona fides with the trade union movement. The Government knows that it cannot pass this legislation into law and therefore its second objective is to prove to the trade union movement that it is trying to do the right thing by it so that it can maintain its support during the election campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: Why does the Government want to retain the support of the trade union movement? Is its only intention in this regard to put forward legislation in relation to superannuation funding or does the Government have other intentions in mind? What is the strategy behind the Government's moves? In a debate on a Bill presented to this House earlier I believe that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) made a master gaffe. To my mind, it exposed the strategy that this Government is using in conjunction with its coalition partners in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In the second reading speech on that earlier Bill, which has not yet passed into law-the Industrial Relations Bill 1987-the Minister had this to say:

The Bill now before the House is not, therefore, to be seen in isolation. It is part of a comprehensive industrial relations strategy which has already demonstrated its effectiveness. The measures contained in this legislation will ensure that the effectiveness of that strategy is further enhanced.

I believe that the Bill now being debated by this House is part of that grand strategy that the Minister was talking about at that time. He was putting before this House certain measures, the effect of which would have been quite dramatic and quite draconian in the field of industrial relations. But he talked also of a grand strategy that both this Government and its coalition partners in the ACTU were quite actively pursuing. I believe that this legislation in relation to superannuation funds and the way in which those funds will be used is part of that grand strategy that the Minister talked about.

There really is not very much in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. The lack of detail and the lack of exposure by the Government make me very concerned about this Bill and what the Government may have in mind. This Bill establishes an Insurance and Superannuation Commission, but it does not go into any detail as to what that Commission will do. It does not give any detail as to how the funds that are contributed to superannuation schemes will be handled. We are told in the Minister's second reading speech that all of that will be handled by regulation, but we are yet to be told what will be contained in those regulations. I have great fear because regulations can slip through this Parliament without any consideration being given to their detail. But that is what is intended in this Bill. The Government is simply setting up a commission and then saying to this House and to the people of Australia: `Don't you worry about that'-we have heard that before-`all the detail will be contained in the regulations'. I wish the Government would come clean and tell us exactly what it has in mind.

I have the gravest suspicion as to what might be intended in the field of superannuation. There is no doubt in my mind that there is a grave need for a national superannuation scheme. We have heard from the honourable member for Richmond, and also from the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who said that there is a grave need for much better retirement provisions in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—My colleague from Franklin agrees with that concept. There is no doubt that the age pensions paid out by the Department of Social Security when people retire are presently an incredible drain on taxpayers and on the Government's Budget. We all realise that much better provisions must be made for retirement benefits. I very strongly support the concept of a national superannuation scheme that can, over a long period, replace that drain on taxpayers. It will be a long time before the effects of any national superannuation scheme become clear. We all know that, but the sooner a national scheme is implemented, the sooner its benefits can become apparent. But this legislation is not intended to set up a national superannuation scheme. Therefore, I believe this House and the people of Australia have every right to question the intentions and the motive behind its introduction.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing at the moment, I believe, is part of a grander strategy by this Government and by the trade union movement to transfer massive amounts of funds to the control of the trade union movement. That may be disputed by my friends opposite, but I believe that that is the grand strategy behind this legislation. Over recent years we have seen a number of schemes set up at the instigation of the trade union movement, schemes such as the building unions superannuation scheme, the allied unions superannuation trust, and so on. These schemes have been set up at the dictate-not even at the instigation, but at the dictate-of the trade union movement. They have been put in place with the `consent' of the employers of this country but at the insistence of the trade union movement, because in a number of instances the trade unions have simply gone to employers who had schemes in place, and said: `You will accept our scheme even though you may want to retain your own scheme'. Of course, through the coercion of the trade union movement, it has been the unions scheme that has prevailed. That is not a choice in superannuation schemes for employees or employers, it is simply a scheme that is foisted on those people by the trade union movement.

If one follows the logic of unions simply pushing schemes on to the employer and the employees of this country, over an extended period it will transfer massive amounts of investment capital to union control because superannuation funds have available massive amounts of capital for private investors to use for future developments in this country. In the not too distant future those huge amounts of capital will not be controlled by superannuation trustees. The trade unions will be the ultimate master of the schemes, behind the trustees and behind the employees who become the investors. It is folly in the extreme to think that we can transfer into the hands of the trade union movement such massive amounts of investment capital because the trade unions can then effectively dictate to private industry how those funds will be used. It will be folly in the extreme if we allow that course to be adopted. I believe that that is part of the grand strategy that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations talked about when he presented his earlier Bill. I am sure that some of his colleagues in the ACTU, such as Mr Crean and Mr Kelty, are also cognisant of that grand strategy.

The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill will lapse and will not pass into law in the course of this Parliament. Therefore, this Government is really doing nothing more than trying to keep favour with its friends in the trade union movement. We need to have a genuine system of national superannuation in this country. It is only through the mechanism of a proper, well-established and universal national superannuation scheme that the onus can be lifted from the social security system and, therefore, from the taxpayers of this country.

As I said earlier, this is not a national superannuation scheme, this is a backdoor method of allowing trade unions to take control of huge amounts of investment capital and, through that method, the private enterprise companies that rely on that investment capital. This does nothing to help in providing security for retirees in the future. People who reach retirement age, need, more than anything else, a flow of cash in their retirement years. Superannuation can provide that, but it does not necessarily do so because it still allows lump sums to be taken in lieu of regular annuities.

This Bill does nothing to change that. Superannuation funds will still be established and paid into regularly by many people over a long period. At the time of their retirement they may still choose to take a lump sum in lieu of an annuity. Having disposed of the lump sum that they have collected they can come back to the social security system, to the taxpayers at the time and say: `I want an age pension'. This Bill does nothing whatsoever to change that. If we are to establish a genuine, national superannuation scheme to change the whole basis of retirement benefits in this country, we need to look seriously at the long term. We need a scheme that will provide not the lump sum cash payment at the end of a person's working life but a flow of cash through the retirement years. This Bill does not even attempt to go down that track.

If we follow the logic of this Bill, which effectively allows people during their working lives, to pay into a superannuation fund under the control of the union movement, and if at the end of their working lives they are able to collect a lump sum superannuation payment and then claim on the social security system, what we are effectively adding to the prospect of people double dipping well into the future. There is no futuristic vision in the way in which this Bill is structured. It does not attempt to grapple with the problems that we face in this country with many people reaching retirement age. It simply transfers into the hands of the union movement many millions of dollars of investment capital. I reject this Bill on that basis. I hope that the House does likewise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you hate unions? What have you got against them?
-Order! The honourable member for Melbourne should not interject from out of his seat.
—My colleague the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), will move an amendment which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a fund established as a result of an employee or employers being threatened, intimidated or coerced by a trade union or trade unions.

I do not think any of us in this place can reject the amendment that has been moved by the shadow Treasurer. Who in this place can say that he would support coercion by a trade union to force employees to become members of a particular superannuation fund? I am sure that none of my friends on the other side of the chamber would openly say that they would support coercion by a trade union of employees to take any particular course of action. I am sure that my friend, the honourable member for Melbourne, would not agree with such a concept. I wish that the honourable member, who is trying to interject, would do it loudly enough for me to hear him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take a point of order.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will not take up the honourable member for Lyons on that offer.

—All of us in this chamber would not accept the concept the employers or employees should be forced by any form of coercion into being participants in a particular form of superannuation or into any other action in which they, as individuals, would not voluntarily want to participate. I believe that is the way in which this Bill is leading the employers and employees of this country. Through the coercive actions of the trade union movement it is effectively forcing employers and employees into that position. I am sorry, I do not accept that concept; I will never accept it. I believe, that, as individuals, they should have a right to choose.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the union movement, along with any other organisation, has the right to offer superannuation to any person, any employee, but the employee must equally have the right to accept or reject the offer that he has made. Once we take away the right of any individual, any citizen, to accept or reject any offer that is made, we are taking away part of the human rights of this country. I cannot accept that. I cannot believe that my friend, the honourable member for Melbourne, would accept that concept. Therefore, I invite my friend from Melbourne, when he makes his contribution to this debate, to reject equally the concepts behind this Bill, just as I do because I am sure that we have similar views on human rights. I reject the concepts behind this Bill. I will not accept that employers or employees should act under any form of coercion. I hope that when the vote is taken on this Bill the House will also reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill are the Government's attempt to catch up with the trade union movement which, on this occasion, as on many others, has been leading the way as to where it wants the Government to go. We have a classic example of that in the past few days with the trade in one of our more important export commodities-namely, wheat and other grains-being held up by the intransigence of the trade union movement because members of the trade union movement think they know more about foreign policy than the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that would be a reasonable decision to come to because the Government does not seem to be getting very far with its foreign policy initiatives in connection with Fiji. Here was a trade union defying the Government and putting at great risk the exports of Australia, yet nobody seemed to be too worried about it. In fact, one of the vilest and most creepy-crawly Press releases has been put out by the Australian Wheat Board today on this subject. It has claimed victory in defeat. It has crawled to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the maritime unions and the unions have eventually condescended-partly, I presume, because of the pressure that has been applied in this place-to send that grain to Fiji. Fiji, of course, was the least concerned about whether the wheat was sent because there are mountains of grain around the world and sellers are desperate for clients. But, had we lost that sale, future sales would have been lost and a $10m a year trade would have been lost to Australia when we so desperately need those sorts of sales to produce the dollars that will put wealth into Australian pockets.

More importantly, the trade unionists who were delaying that shipment are those who would profit most. The reality is that 47 per cent of the value of a tonne of grain at present goes in freight and handling and we know that members of trade unions get most of that.

But this legislation is an example of how the trade unions are also prepared to circumvent the rules put down by government. One of the great economic planks of the Labor Government in office-other than consensus, which was a major plank-was, of course, the accord. The accord was to be a long-standing industrial arrangement that would lead Australia to prosperity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would remind the honourable member that although this has been a wide ranging debate we are not discussing the accord; we are discussing the relevant Bills, which relate to superannuation.
—With due respect, sir, the Bills we are discussing are creatures of the accord. They are here as the result of the Government making deals with trade unions.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor is absolutely wrong in suggesting that the accord has anything to do with these Bills. These Bills, as you have suggested, are very much administrative ones relating to the administration of superannuation. Any suggestion that these Bills are of some value to the trade union movement is itself flawed. They are of value to trustees of superannuation funds.
—You are not making a point of order; you are making a speech.
—I am making a point of order and the honourable member has no right to interrupt me. I have made my point of order.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will desist from speaking until I have heard the Minister's point of order.

—I say again to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the suggestions of the Opposition that these Bills arise out of the accord are fundamentally flawed. These are very narrow Bills about the administration of superannuation.

—Order! I accept the point of order of the Minister. I remind the honourable member for O'Connor that, as I said earlier, there has been a reasonably wide-ranging debate but I should like him to return to the Bills.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. You have made the point that this is a wide-ranging debate and it would be quite unfair to me, as one of the last speakers, suddenly to be confined to these particular Bills because apparently the Minister now wants to deny the accord. It has become so tattered and fragmented that he does not want to know about it any more.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to return to the Bills.

—One of the necessities, Mr Deputy Speaker-and I shall proceed with this and you can stop me if you think appropriate-of stating a case in this Parliament is to be able to put the historical circumstances surrounding the matter. We have some legislation that until recently was unnecessary. It was unnecessary because the Government did not need to control trade union superannuation schemes. Until then we had some other legislation that controlled the superannuation companies, co-operatives or whatever they were, and it was considered adequate. Suddenly, through union action-and, as I say, as a result of the accord; and I was really bringing in the accord only to demonstrate the growth and development of this arrangement-we need this legislation. We have had to tighten the rules. There were some gentlemen in Victoria who went out one day with the superannuation fund cheque book and they bought a house. That is why the Government has brought in these rules. It is absolutely fundamental to this legislation that it was trade union superannuation that created the need for it. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), for a start, suddenly was forced to rush out and state guidelines, and so he should.
—Do you believe there should not be guidelines?

—No, I do not. I believe it is absolutely necessary that we have guidelines because of some of the fellows who are signing the cheques. But the point I make on all of this is that I have been picked up because I bothered to mention the accord. I was about to say to you--
—Order! The honourable member is not reflecting on the Chair, of course.

—No, I am not. In fact, I am reflecting on the Minister who took a point of order and I am entitled to come up with a point of view opposing his argument. The points I want to make are quite simple. We have this legislation because suddenly we have trade unionists controlling superannuation. We have a brand new set of rules. It is compulsory superannuation and, as such, the Government needs to protect the contributors a little more.

SPEECH.PARA: The protection is somewhat limited. A trade union can take a dollar a week out of $11 and now some of those contributions that were $11 or $12 have gone up to $24. They are compulsory contributions from employees who do not start work in the morning unless everybody on the job has a building union superannuation ticket or whatever other sort of ticket is necessary. They may even need a MUST ticket. I might read a little about the MUST ticket. It is a manufacturing unions superannuation trust ticket. The reality is that the Government has had to introduce this legislation so that it can get some idea where the money might be going. I repeat, and it was reported in the Press, that in the early days of this trade union superannuation two blokes went out shopping with the superannuation fund cheque book and they bought a house.

TALK.START.PARA: —A big house?
—Does the Minister think that is a joke?
—I didn't say that; I said: `A big house?'.

—Yes, a big house, and we know all about it. As a result of that, in time one of those trade unionists had to resign as a Minister in the Victorian Government. It is compulsory superannuation and there is the need for this legislation but it is time we became aware of the sort of correspondence that gets sent around the place. This letter has come to me with the compliments of a big mining company. A card is attached to it. The company received this letter, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: SUPERANNUATION-LETTER OF DEMAND You are hereby requested to sign (and if a registered company to seal) the Deed of Adherence to the MUST Scheme (Manufacturing Unions Superannuation Trust), a scheme approved by the Commissioner for Taxation under Section 23f of the Act.
This demand is consistent with the ACTU/Federal Government Agreement on wages, tax and superannuation which recognises that unions can commence bargaining-
one minute it is a demand and the next minute it is bargaining-

for the introduction of industry-wide superannuation schemes. Part of the Agreement is that the demand should be limited to a trade-off against national productivity growth and excepting special circumstances should not create a cost increase prior to 1st July, 1986. This means that by signing the Deed of Adherence with an effective date of 1st July, 1986 you will:-
1. Be covered by the `no extra claims' and `no double counting' undertakings given under the Wage Fixing Principles;
2. You will have discharged your obligations under the Accord in respect to the Productivity claim.
Quite obviously this trade union-and the letter has the ACTU stamp in the corner-believes it had something to do with the accord. The letter continues:

Please note that even if you are currently sponsoring superannuation arrangements for some or all of your employees you should sign up for MUST in addition to those existing arrangements. The minimum contribution required under MUST is $12.50 per week although the Scheme can accept greater amounts. Provision is made for voluntary contributions from employees.

In other words, they can be heavied into paying a bit more; and so on. That is what it is all about and that is why we now have this legislation in the Parliament to try to come to grips with the thousands of millions of dollars that, prospectively, will come into these schemes.

I want to say something about contributors. To a degree the proposal is now a fait accompli. Why is it that if a person is forced into a superannuation arrangement the trade union that has heavied him into it gets a commission? Commissions were paid to people who went out and sold something. They knocked on people's doors, went through proposals with people and went back to see them. Sometimes they put a lot of work into getting a person into a superannuation scheme. Nowadays, when a fella stands at the gate and says `Have you got your ticket?' and the reply is `What ticket?' he says `Your MUST ticket'. If a worker replies that he does not have such a ticket but then he owns his own truck he is told: `That does not matter, mate. Until you have one you don't get through the gate'. We know that that happens. Why does a person have to pay $1 a week to a trade union for the privilege of being forced into such a scheme? Surely if a proprietor, a businessman, an employer, has to pay--

TALK.START.PARA: —My blokes are quite happy.

—If the honourable member for McMillan wants to put an advertisement in a newspaper to the effect that he supports the fact that every one of his constituents who is getting $11 or $24 a week from his employer has to go without $1 or $2 a week of that amount in terms of his end benefit, I will pay for it. I will pay for the advertisement if the honourable member is prepared to tell the people of his electorate that he supports the fact that $2 a week, which could add up to thousands of dollars by the time a person collects his benefit, is better in the hands of his trade union than in his pocket. I object to that principle. We have moved, in our amendments, to ensure that the Australian Taxation Commissioner has a right to stop that sort of bleeding off. If we are to give benefits to workers, for goodness sake let us give them to workers-not to trade union bureaucrats who are fresh out of university. It is a long time since we found many of them with a bit of grease under their fingernails. Some of those trade union bureaucrats have been thinking this thing through for a long time. A submission to the 1981 Australian Labor Party Special National Conference stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of issues raised by the extension of union involvement in Superannuation Schemes. Ultimately these questions include an examination of the investment strategies of those funds and their implications for industrial relations, employment and structural changes in the economy.
Conflicts may arise from those investment decisions. For example, investment in highly profitable areas will maximise the members' retirement benefits-
that sounds a pretty good idea-
but the social consequences of that investment may create a conflict. Obvious examples are investment in Uranium mining or in firms which operate in South Africa.
In other words, the rights of contributors to have the money for their retirement are to be subsumed in politics. The submission continued:

What we must recognise at this early stage of union involvement in the Superannuation issues is that control over the funds will provide unions and governments with considerable financial leverage. That leverage can be used to advance the cause of Socialism in Australia.

That is an exact extract from a submission put to the 1981 ALP Special National Conference. It gives honourable members some idea of how other people view this forced role, to the point that the rights of contributors are secondary to the philosophy of trustees. I have already complained that the legislation does insufficient to demand that any payment made by employers be sent to the fund manager without someone creaming some off on the side for whatever purpose. Such a procedure is unnecessary. First of all, an employer could send a cheque off to a fund manager as easily as he could send it to a trade union whereby it claims some commission which it does not earn, which is a cost to its members. Secondly, if trustees want to impose their philosophy on the investment decisions of the fund, they should be liable for it. The contributor should be protected to the point where he can sue if decisions are taken by the trustee that reduce the overall benefit that he receives at 55 years. No one on the Government benches seems to be speaking, but I would like a response from the Minister on those two points. Why is it that the legislation is deficient in guaranteeing those two fundamental facts?

I think it is a tragedy that it has taken us so long to get such a lousy scheme. I lay some of the blame on my predecessors. Quite obviously, people should have been able to invest in a scheme for their retirement. There are even better mechanisms than the scheme which exists today. I believe that it is totally inequitable that some wage earners can get $4,000 a year deductibility in certain circumstances to invest in superannuation, whereas a small businessman, a self-employed person, has a maximum limit of $1,500.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am looking forward to the release of your policy on this matter.

—I am not defending the previous policy in this area. I think that it has been a long time since we came to grips with the issue. Unfortunately, this is just a development of the mess. Nobody has yet stood back and considered it in a global sense. It is about time that we did so. We must be careful that, in time, these arrangements which I call investment funded retirement schemes do not dominate our economy. We may have to ask ourselves whether people should have a wider scope to invest in their retirement. If they do not do so, we might have so much money in these funds that they become very embarrassing to government and distort the economy. Presently, I believe that is one of the major causes of the inflation-I know the score about foreign money-of our share market. I genuinely believe that, although the present situation is okay, in time we will be forced to consider alternatives-not a change but a mixture.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned for the rights of employees and contributors. I think that that is an honourable position to take. I make it very clear that in government I will be pushing very hard to ensure that trustees will be liable for the decisions they take and there will be no creaming off. If there is to be such a form of compulsory superannuation, I want the benefits to be in the hands of the person who could be considered-the contributor. The contributions that are made by employers are made on behalf of employees. It would have been a much simpler arrangement, I am sure, if in the first instance the money was paid and the workers were given truly portable schemes-a piece of paper in their hands. I do not think that a trade union needs to be the provider of portability. With local government I negotiated an arrangement for local government staff who also move from job to job. It is necessary for them to do so to gain promotion. We put together a suitable scheme for local government staff. We did not do it through their trade union. It struck me at the time that we should have made better provisions for them in terms of their salary and conditions and encouraged them to buy their own piece of paper-a 23fb style scheme-which they would take from job to job where the arrangements would be made. That was an alternative. Nobody thought enough of it in the past.

We now have a scheme of which I am suspicious. It has been conceived with good reasons in terms of the rights of employees and getting them some retirement benefit. I am disappointed that they chose 55 years as the age at which they can basically cash in the benefit. That suggests to me that they will spend it before they reach 65 years and then claim a government pension. That, of course, would be in direct conflict with what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said. He said that the scheme was a great idea because it would reduce taxpayers' contributions to the aged in the future. It will not happen that way. I have considerable doubts about the legislation. I have my doubts on behalf of the workers. I have not heard Government members express that concern in this debate, but no doubt they get their messages from trade unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill. The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill has as its purpose the establishment of the conditions and the supervisory requirements which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds must meet in order to be eligible for concessional taxation treatment under the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill creates a new office to perform these supervisory functions and to be called the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill does away with present offices, who are now to be combined under the one office of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. All that sounds very logical, but earlier in the debate we heard that it may mean the employment of another 300 public servants, which is probably the last thing this country needs.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset of the debate it should be stressed that the way in which the Government has handled the whole issue of superannuation in the four years it has been in office has been not only abysmal but also subject to every thuggerish whim and desire of the trade union movement. Some extraordinary anomalies have arisen in the field of superannuation to which I shall refer shortly. The worst feature about the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill before us is that it gives no details at all of what the Government intends to do. It tells us only that standards will be set that must be adhered to to qualify for tax concessions, but tells us nothing of precisely what the regulations will be. The regulations will not even come up for debate in this House. They will merely be listed in the back of some Government publication and presented to the industry as a fait accompli. This Bill will, in effect, give a carte-blanche for the Government to bring in these regulations at some indeterminate time in the future. I find this an extraordinary situation. The Government talks in the Bill about standards that may be considered. The Bill lists them-and some of them are crucially important factors, such as vesting, preservation and portability-but the Government tells us nothing about what is exactly intended. It is a bit like someone inventing the game of cricket and saying that one has a pitch but not telling one what length it will be; one has some stumps but does not know whether it is two, three or four; one has a ball, but is not told whether it is inflatable, hard or what size it is.

The legislation has no detail about who must contribute, what the penalties are for not contributing, or what time factors and mechanisms the Government has in mind for when the employer's contributions are transferred or vested to the employee. There is nothing about when the employers can get their hands on the money-whether it will be a matter of weeks or whether one must wait until one is 55, 60 or 65 years old. It has nothing as to whether it will be paid as a lump sum, annuity or a proportion of both; it has nothing about whether there will be penalties for early withdrawal or whether, if one withdraws the sum at 65 years and blows it, one can get the pension from then on. We should also consider whether the public will be given a chance to debate the role of the Commissioner and the part he plays in setting the levels of contributions and the principle as to whether or not the Commissioner should have any say at all. Is there to be some debate at some stage on what proportion employers and employees contribute to the scheme? Are the schemes to be made compulsory? That is no minor point because some polls show that 70 per cent to 80 per cent of workers in some industries do not want to participate in the available work schemes.

The questions of concern that workers and those in the superannuation industry legitimately have about this whole area are not here for us to debate tonight. All this Bill achieves is the Treasurer (Mr Keating) telling us that regulations are to be presented in their final form at some indeterminate time in the future. To that extent, the legislation is worthless. The Treasurer may as well put out a Press release telling us what he is going to do and save us all the charade of respectability he is trying to convey tonight.

While I am on the subject of Press releases, many people in the superannuation industry were astounded by the Treasurer's Press release of 9 February that the Government had established a superannuation consultative committee to advise the Government on superannuation legislation and policy proposal implications for the superannuation industry. One might say there is nothing wrong with that, and there is not until one realises that the biggest body of people in this industry who represent the industry were excluded from the committee. I refer, of course, to the Life Underwriters Association of Australia. It alone has over 4,000 members and represents 60 per cent of the professional superannuation and life insurance agents in Australia. They are the people in the field who are dealing every day with the real world situation of superannuation. To exclude them is a bit like the Government drawing up a union policy without consulting the Australian Council of Trade Unions at some stage.

How this Government could deny 60 per cent of the superannuation industry an input into the policy defies comprehension. It is little more than a cynical political exercise. The Government has loaded the committee with its own supporters, with administration-type people who have little or no experience of the every day, real world situation. It would be a bit like setting up a legal committee and stacking it with Labor lawyers. The whole exercise is a political stunt. When it was pointed out to the Treasurer in a letter to him over two months ago, he did not have the courtesy to reply to the Life Underwriters Association of Australia. As a result of refusing to listen to the industry, the Government is now faced with a mounting stack of anomalies in the superannuation area that are crying out to be fixed, but one cannot seem to get a word of reply in this regard from the Treasurer or the Taxation Commissioner.

I will outline a few of the problems which are mounting up and with which the Government seems incapable of dealing. The first problem I will mention is over-funding, because that is an excellent example. Let us take the case of a self-employed person in a superannuation scheme of his own choice who is paying the maximum rate permissible for which he can get tax concessions. If that person wants to do some building work on a building site because he has a contract to do so, before he is even permitted on the building site-as was mentioned earlier by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey)-he is forced to join the building unions superannuation scheme-the BUS scheme. Apart from the repugnance of Australian citizens in this supposedly free country being forced to do this, none of the monetary contributions from this individual will be eligible for tax concessions if he is fully funded under his own scheme and forced into this one.

Let us dwell on this situation for a while: The individual is forced to take out more superannuation that he does not want. In this supposedly free country he is forced to contribute to a union sponsored fund, which in many instances he would not want to do. He is entitled to no tax concessions because he has already used them up in his own scheme. It is pertinent to ask what will happen to those lost concessions and what action this coerced individual can take. At the moment he cannot take any.

Another consideration is what responsibilities the trustees of such funds have in investing such funds, knowing full well that no tax concessions will be available to these funds. I wonder whether the trustees are legally or morally liable for their actions under such circumstances. We have been waiting months for answers from the Taxation Commissioner and the Treasurer to these questions, and they have come up with nothing. The reason is that there are no answers. The solution is to go back and look at the basic cause-union standover tactics in this area. We must be concerned about this Government's capitulation and embracement of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they're not.

—No, they are not; they have done nothing for months. All this compulsory superannuation, and compulsory unionism for that matter, will go when the Liberal Party returns to government come 11 July. Already the position exists in this country where the employers' contributions to the BUS scheme and the allied unions superannuation trust-the AUST scheme-have been increased to $24.50 a week.
—Who pays it?

—The employer pays the lot. Of that amount, $9 is payable to the employee only 39 weeks after he leaves the industry or immediately he retires. He can get the rest at 55 years of age, which is, of course, an advantage over many other schemes. If one looks at the official leaflet of the AUST scheme, one sees that an amount of $1 is put aside each week for administration. I believe the private firms can run these schemes for something like 35c a week. When one considers that there are 120,000 members of the scheme and multiplies that by 65c, which is the amount by which it exceeds the 35c for private superannuation schemes, one realises that $80,000 a week is being put aside.
—Not quite; a bit more.
—I am very interested to hear the confession from the Government that it is putting more aside. At least we have an admission in this area.
—He will soon be the ex-member for McMillan.

—He certainly will be. The drop-out rate of members from the BUS scheme is well over two times that of the industry average. The scheme clearly is being abused. It is being used in many instances as nothing more than a tax dodge and as a way to get a pay rise without paying the normal rates of tax. In other words, it is a rort. The administrative difficulties of this trade union scheme have to be seen to be believed. Already $2.5m has been lost from the scheme. I am told that false names are being used and that many other rorts are in existence. Quite clearly, a tax file number should be given before any contributions can be made and tax concessions given. If that happened it would solve many of the problems in a very simple way. All this raises the question of who should be the trustees of this scheme.
—Norm Gallagher.

—One would hope not, but it has happened. A workers survey shows that no confidence exists in the trade unions dominating these schemes because they might be tempted to make investments with their members' money for reasons not in the best interests of the contributors. Any superannuation scheme surely should at least allow equal representation of employers and employees on the boards. This is especially so when the employers are putting up most of the funds. I would think it obvious that every employer and employee should have the right and the freedom to select the superannuation plan of their choice without the standover tactics that this Government is encouraging and the compulsion that the unions want to see in these schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: The last thing we want to see in Australia is the trade union movement in control of hundreds of millions of dollars of superannuation funds-if not billions of dollars-to be used to implement some of their more dubious political and philosophical aims. If a company like Solo Petrol wants to expand, should the trade unions be able to pour a million dollars of superannuation funds into it? If a trade union venture like Bourke's store is in financial difficulty, should the trade unions be able to use superannuation funds to rescue it? If a company that a trade union scheme has shares in trades with Fiji, a country the trade unions have decided they do not like, will the trade unions pull their superannuation investments out of that country for that reason alone?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Will it collapse its share price unless it takes an uncommercial decision and withdraws its business from Fiji? The honour- able member opposite says no. The trade unions are making political decisions now. They are not sending wheat to Fiji because they do not like the Government over there, so why would they not extend their actions in the manner I have suggested? They have not been sending our wheat to Chile. We are not allowed to trade with South Africa and other countries. These are all political decisions. The extension of trade union power into this area would not surprise me at all. Where are the safeguards in the legislation against all this? I do not see them anywhere. The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, of course, has been party to much of this increase in trade union power in the superannuation area. They should have no role to play in this area at all. Superannuation contributions should be freely given, and should not be at the dictates of the industrial relations club. This body's power should be wound back, not extended.
—It should be abolished.

—That would be a substantial step in the right direction. There should be total preservation of superannuation benefits, until genuine retirement. That is what superannuation is supposed to be all about. One gets the tax concessions now at the taxpayers' expense so that there will not be a drain on the public purse when one retires. The BUS scheme, with its spate of false early retirements, should be stopped immediately. It is abusing this area. The anomalies do not stop there. Take the example of a person who wants his retirement benefits in annuities at the age of 65 but wants to keep on working. That person is liable for tax on that annuity income. Clearly, the legislation should provide an exemption for him in some way.

SPEECH.PARA: We also have the recent trend of trade union representatives giving all sorts of advice on superannuation. If people are to be forced into these schemes surely some sort of registration and education program should be considered to ensure that the advice given is sound. Unions, of course, are using these superannuation schemes as a lever to enforce compulsory unionism. It is a concept totally out of line with the wishes of 80 per cent of Australians. I can tell the House now that that will cease immediately the National Party and the Liberal Party return to government.

In the short time left to me I will give more examples. The first example is about statutory duplication. People may be aware that a considerable portion of the 280,000-odd superannuation schemes in Australia consist of life products only. As such they are controlled and regulated under the existing provisions of the Life Insurance Act. The changes we are debating now will result in these schemes being controlled by the proposed Superannuation Act. So we will have duplication, overregulation and unnecessary costs. The Superannuation Act should, I believe, provide for the exclusion of those schemes that are wholly covered by the Life Insurance Act. If we did this it would avoid the necessity for the filing of annual audit certificates and taxation returns. The trustees of these schemes controlled by the Life Insurance Act could merely be required to lodge with the Superannuation Commissioner a verified statement declaring that the particular scheme is wholly constituted by life assurance products. I believe that would be sufficient.

Another anomaly is in the equity and tax deductions for superannuation contributions. Let me give the example of an average Australian taxpayer who is say 40 years old and earning a salary of $30,000 a year. If he happens to be in an employer sponsored fund, according to a formula based on age, salary and the amount in the fund, that part of the contribution which is paid by the employer is fully deductible up to $6,884-a substantial amount of money. But if this same 40-year-old taxpayer was self-employed, or if he was a non-sponsored employee, the maximum annual deduction he could make would be only $1,500. What an anomaly that is. The present discrimination in this country against the self-employed person-the farmer, the small businessman, and the non-sponsored employee-should be rectified. It is a sham that a self-employed person can register as a proprietary company and then employ himself so that he can get the increased deduction. That is being made more difficult, particularly for professional people.

People with widely fluctuating incomes are affected by the concept of a notional income. For example, a 30-year-old farmer previously could fund up to $95,000 in investment benefits but now under this formula of seven times notional salary-which I will not go into now-he is restricted if his salary is, say, $7,500, as it is for many farmers, to funding a maximum benefit of $52,500. In other words, it has been cut to about a quarter of what it was before. This is doing nothing to encourage younger taxpayers to put aside funds to invest.

At the Committee stage we will be moving amendments to the effect that regulations that come down later should come before Parliament first for debate. We will be moving other amendments to do with the Superannuation Commissioner. This legislation is badly thought out. It contains all the elements of trade union coercion which we find repugnant in this country and, overall, it needs substantial amendment before it is thrust upon the Australian people.

I am sure that the Minister for Community Services (Mr Hurford) when he sums up will have many points to make about some of the ridiculous measures proposed by Opposition members tonight.
