SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take part in the debate on the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill. There are two unfortunate things about this debate. First, the circumstances in which it occurs and, secondly, the inadequacies of the legislation now before the House. This debate occurs in circumstances where this country has been tormented by economic difficulties. Wage levels should be maintained at present levels so that we can become competitive with our international trading partners. Productivity levels do not justify a hidden wages increase.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I believe that it is wrong to bring those issues into this debate. Ultimately, this nation must have a coherent superannuation scheme, but not necessarily a government run scheme. This country requires that everyone in the community is assured that on reaching retirement age he will have available to him a stream of income that provides an adequate minimum standard of living. Furthermore, we want a scheme that provides to those who choose to postpone expenditure from their working years to their retiring years reward for that effort and benefit in their retirement and not penalty as now applies under assets tests and cruel incomes tests. This debate has become somewhat muddy because there are those whose concern about our high wage levels dominates their minds, and they lose sight of the real issues upon which we should be focusing.

The second reason why I think that this legislation has come in in unfortunate circumstances is that it talks about superannuation, yet it fails adequately to define what is meant by superannuation. Payments into superannuation funds receive substantial tax benefits. When most people talk about superannuation they think of it in terms of their retirement. What is important in retirement is a consistent stream of income over the retirement years-whether they are long or short.

For many years I have advocated the major reform of our social security system. I believe that even today the most effective and efficient way to build national superannuation security for the whole of the nation is to provide a basic flat rate pension for all free of an assets test or an income test, and then allow people to provide above that level at whatever level they choose. If they want to save during their working lives so they can spend it in retirement, good luck to them. If they want to enjoy their earnings while they are working, they cannot expect to have it twice over at public sector taxpayer expense.

Some argue that the approach I take is very expensive-I do not believe that it is. I believe that the present income and assets tests heavily distort people's pre-retirement saving and investment patterns and heavily distort their early retirement expenditure patterns. As a result, many hundreds of thousands of Australians feel cheated on reaching retirement. They feel that they have paid their taxes only to pay other people's pension and on retirement, because of their frugalness and the sacrifices they have made during their working lives, they are denied.

The fairest way is to have a universal flat rate pension. I would go one step further and say that with such a flat rate pension, people must pay the present level of taxes. If a hidden wage increase is available because employers or employees are contributing to a superannuation fund-or if the self-employed want to contribute to a fund-people should be entitled to a tax deduction only if its value is invested in their superannuation funds and made available to them on retirement as a stream of income. If that does not happen, no tax deductibility should be available to them. That is one area in which the Bill is deficient, because it does not define superannuation as a stream of income in retirement. At the age of 55, people can take out the tax benefits available on contributions to superannuation funds, spend them all and then come back to the next generation of taxpayers and say: `I am poor, I have no income, you pay me a pension'.

High, middle and low income earners are, in increasing numbers, double dipping. While that happens, people will more and more expect the Government to provide the underpinning for their social security program. People should be able to opt out of paying tax provided that they opt out of receiving an age pension. For that reason, it is necessary that there be standards for superannuation funds, that retirement ages be set and that vesting provisions be laid down. As contributions to superannuation funds are part of the wages package, the vesting period should be very short indeed. The old-fashioned, paternalistic days where an employer could lock his employee into his employment have gone. Therefore, vesting should be short-12 months or even less. In some industries people move from employer to employer, to the benefit of all concerned. There should also be preservation until retirement, be it 65 or whatever age is set. It is now 65 for men and, perhaps, in these days of non-discrimination, it should be the same age for all. There should also be maximum opportunity for portability and, where that cannot be arranged, preservation within a number of funds should be guaranteed.

It may well be asked why there should be government intervention in superannuation funds. It is for two reasons only. Firstly, I wish to talk about why there should be public policy for superannuation and private provision for retirement. Governments have a responsibility to assure every Australian of an income in retirement. If, as I believe, the taxpayers are tired of paying taxes, they must be given room to provide for their own retirement. In effect, the Government should set up a compulsory regime under which everybody would be required either to pay taxes or to provide for retirement. As tax exemptions are given on the contributions to superannuation funds and on the income of those funds, those resources should fulfil their public sector government policy purpose, namely, the assurance of a stream of income to the contributors and members of funds on the attainment of the age of retirement. The tax provision should be equitable and fair to all and the tax benefit should not be greater for a contribution by an employer than it is for a contribution by an employee. The tax exemption for savings in a superannuation fund and for the income of that fund should be no greater than the tax exemption-which currently does not exist-available to a private individual who saves privately for retirement.

We must ask how, in those circumstances, we can assure that those funds are available as a stream of income in retirement. I do not believe that it is beyond the wit of this Parliament to devise ways and means whereby those who wish to save privately are required to give appropriate contingent security over assets-whether it be their homes or other investments-so that if they exhaust all other means of providing an income, there is an asset upon which the Government can call in lieu of the pension that it would then have to pay. We want neutrality in the tax system, but it does not exist today for individual private provision for retirement. Indeed, the present tax regime is not fair to the community because those on high incomes can obtain huge tax exemptions, where as those on low incomes obtain only low tax exemptions.

In today's Australia, the middle and low-income earners are so heavily taxed by the Government-as they were by past governments-that they cannot afford to save for their retirement. In any event, if they can afford it, they recognise that they will be punished and penalised by the high withdrawal mechanisms of the present income test, with the assets test now to overlay that. They think that it is not worth it. Yet those with higher incomes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Many suffering unemployment cannot afford it.

—Many people cannot afford it because the taxes are so high and, indeed, because the penalty is so high when they do make the sacrifice. Many on higher incomes obtain huge tax benefits through the present deductibility of contributions by employers as well as by employees. Those who are penalised are the self-employed, the farmers and those who try to save privately. We need to examine our policy objectives, but this legislation fails to do that. We need to ensure that the taxpayers' role is to give encouragement to private provision for retirement in place of the public sector pension.

SPEECH.PARA: I began my remarks by saying that I believed in a universal flat rate pension, and I do. Under the present arrangements it is the most sensible, rational and fair way to proceed. Then, we can progressively relieve government of that expenditure by encouraging individuals, through tax relief, to replace a tax-funded social security pension with their own private provision, whether it be through superannuation funds or privately by the development of the new security arrangements that I have briefly outlined.

There is much that I would have liked to have said, but others wish to take part in the debate. I conclude by saying that until this country recognises that the cost of dependency will not go away while we continue to have the great expansion in expectation of life-nor would we wish it to do so-we must face the reality that an ever-declining proportion of our population will have to provide either directly or indirectly the resources for a stream of income to those in retirement. Even if we have private sector superannuation we will still find that the working population provides the retirees with the investment income that gives them their support.

We need to develop a rational and fair scheme, a scheme that allows Australians to co-operate together so that whether they are in the work force, out of work or in retirement, an adequate standard of living is available to all-a standard of living over which individuals have some degree of choice as to whether they spend now or later; a standard of living which gives people an incentive and, having given them an incentive, rewards them for postponing expenditure until retirement. This would have many side benefits. It would not merely provide relief to taxpayers when they reach retirement; it would provide substantial investment funds which would help to enable this country to trade into more prosperous times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is considering a package of superannuation legislation-the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. I will not delay the House for long in order to accommodate others who wish to speak during the adjournment debate. I would like to pick up some points that were made by the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), particularly in regard to access to superannuation generally. I point out that many of the people listening to the broadcast of this debate or perhaps working on their tractors in the electorate of Farrer do not have access to superannuation because of their particular circumstance, be it self-employment or a circumstance related to the tough economic times which means that they simply cannot afford to go down the path, notwithstanding the will to do so of providing in a comprehensive way for their individual superannuation requirements in retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, therefore, that the House ought to be reminded here and now in the closing stages of the second reading debate on this superannuation package, that this legislation does not even begin to apply to quite a large group of Australians, quite a large group of small business operators and quite a large group of primary producers who are bearing the brunt of the tough economic times which have been brought about by this Government. I refer particularly to high interest rates, but there is a range of other factors, some of which are beyond the control of government, I am quite prepared to admit, such as low commodity prices or the severe drought conditions which are re-emerging over much of South Australia, much of south-western New South Wales and indeed, many other areas of rural Australia. In considering this legislation the House ought to be conscious of the fact that so many fall through any net created by this package of legislation. The House ought to realise that point in terms of the end gain faced by so many when they get to their retirement phase.

Of course, embraced by this legislation is the creation of yet another quango. I want to express some concern in relation to specific aspects. An assessment has been made that this legislation in itself will provide for the appointment of yet another 300 public servants to carry out some of the administration associated with the provisions of this package of superannuation legislation. Again, that is hardly a commendable way to go in terms of creating a climate of less government, less taxation, more incentive and more productivity, which this country needs so much and which I hope, following the election on 11 July, this country will receive.

What this legislation does, of course, is to accommodate the sweetheart deal done by this Government with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and with the trade unions generally, in the provision of a number of measures associated with bedding down superannuation. Other members who have spoken, including the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and the honourable member for Sturt, have dwelt on this point. I will not go into details except to concentrate on two major areas. Again, I point out to the House that in this legislation we have government by Press release. We have legislation by Press release. Indeed, the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), in his second reading speech, referred directly to the Press releases of 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986 in which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced various operating standards which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds-ADFs-will be required to meet in order to be eligible for relevant taxation concessions.

Press releases are being presented to the nation at large which will be made binding by subsequent legislation. I think this has gone on for long enough. This elected Parliament-the House of Representatives and the Senate-has been taken for granted. Governments issue Press releases and say `This is how the law will pertain to a particular area', be it in relation to media ownership, superannuation taxation concessions, or whatever. I sound a note of warning: After 11 July the new non-Labor government will not want to go down this path. It will be redeeming in terms of its application of the legislative procedures of the national Parliament. I think it is very regrettable-and I know that the Minister for Community Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford) is somewhat embarrassed by this-that yet again government by Press release is embraced by this legislation.

The second area on which I want to dwell in the limited time available to me is the other unsatisfactory aspect of the whole package whereby so much will be left to provisions by regulation rather than specific provisions in the Bills that are before the House. My good colleague the honourable member for Richmond, who is heading for yet another record majority in his electorate, has drawn my attention to the wide provisions which will be dealt with by way of regulation, which is removed from the direct parliamentary process. Although the provisions will be able to be referred to the Parliament for further consideration and disallowance, in effect the bureaucrats prefer legislation to be dealt with in this manner so that they can have their way in the best Yes Minister tradition which has beset the Westminster system too often in both the United Kingdom and Australia.

If time allowed I would refer, for example, to the 14 different provisions under clause 7 (2) of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill with regard to what can be prescribed by way of regulation. They range over such subjects as the persons who may contribute to superannuation funds, the vesting in members of superannuation funds of benefits arising directly or indirectly from amounts contributed to superannuation funds, and so on. It is a frightening example of government by regulation, and legislation by way of regulation, rather than by specific provision. I know that even you, Mr Deputy Speaker, in your learned way, would be very conscious of these provisions in the Bill, but I know that I am not allowed to dwell on that point. The danger in the superannuation equation facing this nation is that this Parliament and this Government, by way of this legislation, are creating what will ultimately become a monster which will engulf small business, big business and the viability of this nation to provide for those in the retirement phase.

I close by saying that I fully recognise the need for superannuation and the need for provisions to be made for retirement. But I also recognise the hundreds of thousands of Australians who fall outside the scope of this legislation and who are facing the most horrific economic times in that other economy, unbeknownst to the Treasurer who regales us day after day with the stories about the top end of the economy and fails to admit any knowledge or understanding of the other end of the economy-the economy in rural Australia. There is direct suffering in that sector. Families in that sector suffer from diet deficiencies as a consequence of the hardship that exists. There is a resurgence of drought conditions of the most horrific nature. This Government will lose office on 11 July because of its failure to recognise that there are two economies side by side in this nation-one that it has tried to deal with and one that it has ignored time and time again. I sound the note of warning that in this legislation there are a number of aspects of considerable concern. I look forward to their being dealt with in more detail at the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar led for the Opposition and, as I indicated earlier, admitted that the legislation was overdue. I set the challenge before him again to work with me to make sure that the legislation goes through the Parliament. As most people know, the Government is in office-not in power, because it does not have the majority in the Senate. We require the co-operation of the Opposition. I appeal to the Opposition and set it the challenge to make sure that this legislation is through before next Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mackellar, as did the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and others in this debate, said that he was worried about standards being in regulations, not in legislation. But the honourable member for Mackellar did not make the mistake that the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) made when addressing himself to this subject. The honourable member for Parkes suggested that the regulations would not come before the Parliament. Of course the regulations come before the Parliament and the Parliament is given the opportunity to disallow those regulations. The honourable member has been here long enough to know that.

Let me address the problem in greater detail. The matters to be covered by regulations will essentially give legislative effect to the standards that were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 11 June, 30 July and 22 December. The principles reflected in these standards are well understood in the industry generally. However, as with any complex and technical requirements of this kind, the Government knows that it can work much more constructively with the industry in implementing the standards if there is the flexibility to adjust readily the standards where practical difficulties arise or where they are proving unduly costly for industry. Once we have gone through those early stages of consultation with the industry and come up with these regulations, maybe at some later stage, if there is merit in it, we can put those regulations in legislation. But at this stage that greater flexibility is of great value to the industry. The key industry bodies are working with the Government to complete the regulations and have expressed support for this approach. As I have said to the honourable member for Parkes and others, the regulations will of course be open to scrutiny when they are made.

Let me now say something about the standards because, as I have said, they are known and have been released. The Government's occupational superannuation standards are reasonable by any objective measure and the requirements involved represent little more than those which should in any case be observed by well managed superannuation funds. The requirements are very modest when compared with those under the Life Insurance Act which are applicable to life insurance companies. While the key industry bodies-I am referring to the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia-support the general thrust of the standards, it might be noted that they have been actively urging the Government to adopt more stringent requirements in some areas, particularly with respect to the vesting and preservation requirements. Of course, we are taking that into account. But some of the flexibility that we need at this stage, which is giving rise to making the decision to put the standards in regulations rather than in the legislation, may lead to our being able to accommodate the industry. On the other hand, there are some less responsible elements in the industry who are not interested in upgrading the role of occupational superannuation and who would prefer to impede implementation of these regulatory arrangements in order to allow scope for the development of tax based abuses such as the now outlawed cherry picker and loan-back schemes. We do not want the opportunity for these things to arise again. I therefore again urge the Opposition to work with us to make sure that this Bill becomes an Act before 1 July. Clearly, superannuation funds can perform their appropriate long term role only if their operations are more closely directed towards meeting the community's retirement needs.

One or two honourable members mentioned the Life Underwriters Association. I have spoken with that body. For instance, I was with the Tasmanian branch in Launceston only the week before last. That body has not raised any substantive points against the standards as such. The issues raised by that body have been more concerned with existing tax provisions and these matters are for the Government to study in the context of the Income Tax Assessment Act and not in the context of this superannuation legislation. It is important to follow on with the administration of the standards in order to ensure that the interests of superannuation beneficiaries are adequately protected. The legislation will achieve this by making the trustees of superannuation funds much more accountable to their members and by imposing requirements, such as vesting requirements and preservation requirements among others, which will provide for superannuation benefits to be more closely directed towards meeting members' retirement needs.

The honourable member for Mackellar and others also raised the cost of administration. The superannuation standards will be administered in the most cost-effective way. The Government knows that it has struck a reasonable balance between imposing worthwhile standards on the one hand and avoiding unduly burdensome and costly regulations on the industry on the other hand. Is anybody going to suggest that $30 per fund is unduly burdensome? The administration of this will be a major task with those 300,000 superannuation funds involved as they are. It is estimated that a total of 77 staff, not 300, the number that has been bandied around in this chamber, will be required to perform this week. However, most of the required staffing resources will come from the 66 positions devoted to this work in the Australian Taxation Office. That means an extra 11 staff as against the figure of 300 that comes from the imagination of some members of the Opposition. By some of their remarks we could be forgiven for thinking that they would want Rafferty's rules to continue. Perhaps they want the abuses to continue but I hope that is not the case. I hope indeed that they will want us to put into effect those minimum vesting standards, those minimum preservation standards, the portability of benefits, the security of benefits standards and the membership requirements of trustees boards. I also trust that we will get on with something which arises from this Bill and which improves the reporting requirements.

I could read out the details that are already in the statement made by the Treasurer on 11 June 1986 when he set out the details of these standards, but time is short in the Parliament. We have a Committee stage on this Bill, which I hope will be facilitated by the Opposition so that we can get the Bill through the House of Representatives tonight. I am pleased that the Opposition is not opposing this Bill. I trust that it will also facilitate the Bill going through the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 3, at the end of the definition of ``superannuation fund'' add the following words and paragraph:

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will identify whether coercion or intimidation has been applied?

—The honourable member for Charlton said that this is a provocative provision. I will explain exactly to honourable members what the provision means. It is perfectly simple. If an employee does not want his or her life savings to be invested in a particular fund, or if the employer does not want to make a contribution into that fund, he should not have to, and it is absolutely wrong that as a result of coercion from a trade union-it has happened and it is a real fact of life-people should be required to put their own life savings or people who are contributing towards the life savings of their employees should be required under law to place that money in a fund which is not of their choice. In the very same way that the Liberal and National parties believe in non-compulsory unionism, in other words freedom of association, a very basic human liberty-we will in office conduct a referendum to allow the Australian population to confirm that it would prefer voluntary unionism-we are simply not prepared to allow people to be forced to place their life savings in investment vehicles of which they do not approve. I have investigated the way in which these funds have been set up. I have talked to people, to contractors on sites who were threatened with being put out of business if they did not force their employees to do this. SPEECH.PARA: People talk about agreement being reached between employers and unions within the building industry about the setting up of these funds. That agreement is arrived at under threat of loss of livelihood by those employers and the people working with them. I have chapter and verse on that. We are fighting for basic human rights, the right of every person to plan for his retirement in a way in which he would want to; the rights of employers to contribute out of the profits and earnings of a business to provide for their employees safeguards in retirement in a way which they deem to be appropriate. The fact of the matter is that if this matter is subjected to free, honest and open choice, those funds would not exist or, alternatively, they would exist in a much reduced form. —The honourable member for Kalgoorlie ought to understand--
—Order! The honourable member will not respond to interjections. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie will cease interjecting.
—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie says that I have never been on a building site. He ought to know--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is nothing more, nor less, than an exercise in political gimmickry. I point out that no one on this side of the chamber wants coercion to take place in these circumstances. We are denying that there is general coercion in this particular field of conduct. Twenty-five million years ago, at an area about half way up the eastern seaboard of Australia, the volcanoes ruled. The entire region was alive with the smell and sound of molten rock exploding from the Earth.

However, the mysterious geological forces controlling the eruption soon shifted away, leaving ten mountains as a permanent legacy. As the eras passed, the mountains wore back, until only the hard rock cores remained, jutting out of the plain. It was this group of monoliths that James Cook saw during his 1770 voyage of discovery, and named the Glasshouse Mountains.

The settled volcanic ash from the ancient volcanoes made the surrounding soils very fertile, and when white man settled the area, many farming townships were established. One of these towns is now called Woodford, and has now been my home since 1983.
Woodford, a community of about one thousand residents, could be called a typical country town. There are the shops, the hotel, and the people you soon identify with a home town.

While there is not much in Woodford itself that is unique, the surrounding area is such that anybody appreciating the challenge of reaching the top of a mountain, or who likes the relaxation of a bush swimming hole, can find much to enjoy.

So far, I have reached the peaks of six Glasshouse mountains. Most have only been about two hours cycling from town, and the difficulty of the climbs has ranged from a simple walk to places where one slip could mean the end. However, in all cases, the rewards are worth the efforts.

My bushwalking experiences have taken me further afield than the Glasshouse region. Indeed, since my parents are teachers, I have lived in many different areas of the State in the last seventeen years. I was born in the granite-belt town of Stanthorpe, and since then I lived in areas as the Gulf of Carpentaria, as well as an Aboriginal Community near Cairns, and the metropolis of Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to draw the attention of the House to the activities of a group known as D. F. The prospectus referred to Winston Gardens townhouses and resulted in trust No. 126 being formed. The modus operandi was very simple. The company issued prospectuses which were very promising on capital growth in private trusts. It encouraged people to invest in unit trusts and guaranteed quite considerable returns. It was suggested that, for a $385,000 capital investment, there would be a growth rate of 75 per cent in a five-year period which was, of course, tax free. It is fascinating to note that in the first year of operation this group took $66,500 out of a $385,000 investment for manager expenses, trust formation fees, formation costs, legal fees and stamp duty. I repeat: The group took $66,500 out of a total public investment of $385,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The group made a great number of promises to people who trusted it to do what the prospectuses said it would do. It promised that in trust No. 126 they would receive a percentage increase on their equity of 74 per cent over a five-year period. This was estimated as a capital appreciation of $221,000. In a letter to all members of unit trust No. 126, the group stated that the trust had been `seriously affected, partly by the downturn in the market over the first four years but mainly by regulations introduced by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission in July 1982'. It went on to say that regulations were imposed on private trusts to stop the uncontrolled sale of units and that the abolition of negative gearing had affected that particular trust.

I wrote to the firm and asked how that affected capital growth on a block of flats. Of course, it cannot answer that question. The group has told an untruth to the aged, widows and other investors who have put their life savings into these trusts by suggesting that capital growth has not been achieved because of the abolition of negative gearing. The abolition of negative gearing has not affected the ability of any of those unit trusts, private or public, to gain capital growth. I intend to issue a Press release tomorrow and I hope that the matter will be picked up by the national media so that everyone involved with this darned group will find out the truth-that it has failed. It was not very accurate in its original forecasts. It has pocketed the $66,500 and now, five years down the track, when the unit trusts do not have the capital growth, it says: `Okay, we will now form a public company and transfer your unit into a share in the public company. When I wrote to the group I asked it whether it had made a valuation of trust No. 126. I asked it whether it could inform the investors of trust No. 126 of the capital growth. It cannot even tell the investors, despite asking them to go into a public company, whether their individual trust has achieved a capital growth. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Word Processing or Computer Equipment and Repetition Strain Injury

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 17 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What word processing or computer equipment has been introduced into the Minister's Department and statutory authorities responsible to the Minister since 1982.
(2) Why was the equipment purchased and were any specific targets set in terms of time or cost savings and improved efficiencies.
(3) What has been the cost of purchasing the equipment.
(4) Has the introduction of the equipment necessitated the purchase of new office equipment; if so what have been the costs of the additional purchases.
(5) Has the introduction of the equipment led to changes in work practices; if so, what has been the nature of the changes.
(6) What has been the incidence of repetition strain injury (RSI) in the Minister's Department since 1982.
(7) How many lost working days have been caused by RSI related illnesses since 1982.

(8) How many persons have been forced to retire from the Minister's Department or statutory authorities responsible to the Minister as a result of RSI and what have been the compensation costs of this early retirement.
(9) Has introduction of the equipment:
(a) saved money; and
(b) improved efficiency in the Minister's Department or the statutory authorities responsible to the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Details of equipment
DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE (CENTRAL OFFICE)
Word processing equipment

This Department's Word Processing System is entirely comprised of Wang equipment. Since 1982 the Department has introduced an additional OIS 140 Central Processing Unit (CPU) which was upgraded to a VS100 CPU in 1985. Additional workstations, printers, personal computers and other associated hardware items have also been purchased together with appropriate software.
Computer equipment

The Department of Finance has used large-scale computer facilities to aid in the processing of its major, Service-wide accounting systems for many years and the purchases since 1982, for the most part, were for the continuation, expansion or improvement of those systems and replace or supplemented functionally similar equipment previously in use.

Computer equipment purchases since 1982 which form part of the Department's Central Computer facilities include an Amdahl mainframe computer, IBM compatible disk storage, laser printers, terminal equipment, microcomputers and microfiche equipment.
Purchases for the Regional Office network computer facilities have included Nixdorf-based data entry and computer systems, terminal equipment and mini computers.
AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT RETIREMENTS BENEFITS OFFICE (AGRBO)
A Wordplex 8000 word processing system comprising 16 workstations and 7 printers was purchased during 1985.
Computer equipment purchases since 1982 have included terminal equipment, microcomputers, disk drives and a Nixdorf 8890 Network Node Computer and associated software.
SUPERANNUATION FUND INVESTMENT TRUST (SFIT)
SFIT uses IBM personal computers for all its word processing requirements.
Computer equipment purchased by SFIT since 1982 falls into two main categories:

32 printers and associated printer equipment; and
2 plotters.
Mainframe Computing

4 extra terminals to the HP 3000;
3 extra printers; and
11 modems and associated communications equipment.
Some computing equipment associated with a new PABX system has also been purchased.
(2) Reasons for purchase.
DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE (CENTRAL OFFICE)

With the growth of the Department and the outposting of word processing equipment to Departmental executive areas, there has been an ongoing requirement to expand and update the Word Processing System in order to provide an efficient service to the Department. The original OIS 140 was operating at full capacity in 1981 which necessitated the purchase of a second OIS 140 CPU. By 1984 both OIS 140s were operating at full capacity which significantly reduced the response time of work being generated and limited further expansion of the System. This then necessitated the upgrade to the present VS100 System which was purchased in July 1985. Since that time the VS100 has adequately handled the work load and improved the efficiency of the Word Processing System. Its use has avoided any increase in turn around time in producing material, particularly in the need to meet Cabinet and Parliamentary Committee Schedules.

Micro computers were introduced into the Department since 1982 to facilitate the use of information systems, management decision systems, econometric modelling, production of graphics output and similar management aids. Their acquisition has been in response to increasing demands for quick but detailed analysis for resource evaluation and management purposes.

The allocation of computer workstations (microcomputers, terminals and printers) since 1982 has been based on the demonstrated needs of individual areas within the Department, and allocation priorities have been agreed by an ADP Planning Committee comprised of senior officers.

Specific targets and cost savings have not been defined for the purchases, which were generally undertaken chiefly to meet work load growth or needs for analytical capacity. While many of the benefits gained relate to the quality of decision making there have also been benefits in output/staff ratios and in timeliness and accuracy of results.
AGRBO
Word processing equipment was purchased to replace existing outdated equipment and to improve the Office's capacity to meet increased workload demands.
Targets were to achieve a 24 hour turnaround in keyboard activity and to meet increased workload demands through increased productivity.

Computing equipment purchases were made to improve the delivery of service to clients, to facilitate access to the Department of Finance network and to meet increased workload demands through increased productivity.
SFIT
The equipment was purchased for two reasons:
to provide an appropriate environment for systems developed to meet criticisms of SFIT's operations by the Auditor-General; and
to improve information services in support of investment analysis, transaction processing, financial reporting and office systems.

DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE (CENTRAL OFFICE) AND AGRBO

(5) Change in work practice.
DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE (CENTRAL OFFICE) AND AGRBO
Word processing equipment

Computer equipment

significantly faster and more detailed analyses of investments are now possible;

control and production of SFIT accounting records and reporting has improved substantially, including the preparation of quarterly financial statements on a full market value basis; and
most staff have been trained in computer usage with the result that personal computers and terminals are now regularly used by the majority of staff.

9. Savings and efficiency.
DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE (CENTRAL OFFICE) AND AGRBO
(a) Word processing equipment

Given that the Department has expanded and the work load has increased considerably, it is difficult to objectively determine monetary savings on a comparative basis. However, the introduction of word processing equipment has resulted in a more efficient and effective service to the Department, with a significantly improved workload response time and a higher standard of output. In the absence of the equipment, staff growth would have been considerable or, alternatively, the quality and timeliness of the functions performed by the Department would have been substantially degraded.
(b) Computer equipment

No attempt has been made to quantify the overall benefits achieved through the introduction of computer workstations and microcomputers in Finance, although consideration is given to cost-effectiveness arguments when the ADP Planning Committee allocates priorities for the installation of computer workstations.

Opportunities for further efficiency improvements are offered via the ``bureau'' service provided by the Department (Finance Ledgers, Budget Management, Public Service and General Payments Systems etc) with the increasing interfacing of computer workstations which are being installed in other Government agencies.
Savings that have been made result from improved efficiency and, as previously stated, cannot be readily quantified, but the improved efficiency has been rated as significant.
SFIT

SFIT's objective is to maximise the rate of return on the Fund having regard to the need to make provision for payments, the need for equity between contributors and the need to exercise care and prudence.

SFIT is also required to observe other obligations specified in the Superannuation Act 1976 such as external reporting to the Parliament and contributors, planning, record-keeping and the maintenance of efficiency in its operations.

Investments in information systems are evaluated against these criteria and SFIT is satisfied that the investments made since 1982 have contributed to the achievement of its objectives, including efficiency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 23 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What Government subsidies, benefits or financial assistance is available to the primary industry sector?
(2) What assistance is available to primary producers in terms of excise duties on fuel and the availability of subsidised interest rates through rural schemes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The rural sector benefits from measures directed not only to primary producers but also to the wider rural community.

Those measures which are specifically directed to primary producers include measures designed to address on and off-farm costs, and to encourage greater efficiency in all aspects of rural sector activities from production to marketing.

Steps taken to reduce on-farm costs embrace a wide range of inputs including agricultural chemicals, fuel, fertilisers, agricultural machinery, soil and water conservation measures, and fodder storage. They take various forms-rebates, tax concessions, direct subsidies-and include:
(i) removal of the 2 per cent general revenue duty on imported agricultural chemicals thus giving a tariff concession to the farm sector.

Tariffs on all chemicals and plastics, including agricultural chemicals, are to be phased down over the next 3-5 years from current levels of around 30 per cent to a maximum level of 15 per cent. This will reduce farm input costs by an estimated $2-4 million per annum in agricultural chemicals alone. Rural producers will also benefit from the effects of the reduction of tariffs on other inputs.

(ii) payment of a subsidy under the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme on the cost of freighting eligible petroleum products to country locations. The level of subsidy is equal to the difference between the actual freight cost and the maximum consumer contribution. Currently the maximum consumer contribution is 5.7 cents per litre. In 1986/87 these subsidy payments are estimated to cost $24 million.
(iii) full rebate of the excise on diesel used off road. Further information about this is given in the answer to question 2.

(iv) subsidies on locally produced phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers to encourage local production and use of fertilisers. New rates introduced on phosphatic fertilisers in August 1986 were $153, $163 and $188 per tonne of phosphorous where phosphorous content is less than 10 per cent, 10-15 per cent and more than 15 per cent, respectively. This represents an increase over the previous rate of $138 per tonne of phosphorous. The rate on nitrogenous fertilisers has continued unchanged at $20 per tonne of nitrogen. The cost of the subsidy on both items is estimated at $43m in 1986/87.

(v) grants made to the States to offset the cost to farmers of dumping duties on imported fertilisers. Payments are made to importers to refund the dumping duty collected by the Australian Customs Service and corresponding payments are made to local manufacturers of those fertilisers. In 1986-87 these payments are estimated to cost about $40 million.
(vi) substitution of bounties for tariffs on grain harvesters, cultivation equipment and tractors at a cost of around $4 million, $17 million and $2 million a year respectively.
(vii) exemption from sales tax on most agricultural machinery and equipment and also on certain (4-wheel drive) vehicles used off-road
(viii) special depreciation rates on some forms of expenditure
grain, hay or fodder storage facilities are depreciable over 3 or 5 years
the capital cost of a telephone line is depreciable over 10 years.
(ix) special tax deductions
soil conservation and land degradation expenditure is immediately deductible
expenditure on conserving or conveying water is deductible over 3 years
As regards off-farm costs, primary producers receive assistance through:

(i) subsidisation of export inspection costs. The Commonwealth meets at least 50 per cent and, in some instances, more than 50 per cent, of the cost of inspection services at a cost of around $56 million a year. Products covered are meat, wool, grain, fruit and vegetables, fish, dairy products, eggs and livestock.

Further benefits will flow to producers through the Commonwealth's initiative to rationalise and streamline the Export Inspection Service and to establish a single national meat inspection service, with the Commonwealth having responsibility for inspection of all meat for domestic and export markets. This will avoid duplication of effort, making inspection services more cost efficient.

(ii) subsidisation of fisheries management. Of the effective Australian Fisheries Service budget of $12.2 million for management and policy formulation purposes, $10.3 million relates to fisheries management. The Commonwealth pays 56 per cent of the operational costs incurred in the management of the Northern Prawn Fishery and Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery, where management plans exist, and 100 per cent of the operational costs for the South Eastern Trawl, Southern Shark, East Coast Tuna, West Australian Offshore and Great Australian Bight fisheries, where no management plans currently exist.

Additional benefits will flow from Government action to reduce regulation, increase the efficiency of transport services, and to establish a Royal Commission to inquire into the costs and efficiency of the national grain transport, storage and handling systems.

In addition to the above, the rural sector benefits from a number of broad-ranging measures designed to encourage greater industry efficiency in both production and marketing and, where appropriate, to, provide direct assistance to protect industry returns. These include
(i) measures which address the problems arising from the fluctuating nature of primary producers' incomes
income tax averaging
indefinite carry-forward of losses

Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme (IEDS), which offers an attractive rate of interest to encourage farmers to save in good years to provide a source of liquidity during poorer years. Deposits are currently in the order of $50 million.

underwriting schemes which apply to wheat, apples and pears, dairy products and dried vine fruits. While no payments are expected to be made in respect of these products in 1986-87, they nonetheless involve a substantial contingent liability for the Commonwealth and play an important role in stabilising farm production and incomes.
(ii) discriminatory pricing schemes maintained for certain dairy products, sugar, dried vine fruits, canning fruit and eggs.

(iii) the sugar adjustment plan which is designed to ensure the long term efficiency of the industry in Queensland and New South Wales. In 1986-87, the first year of the three year plan, the Commonwealth Government is providing $22.6 million to the industry, and will provide up to $100 million over the three year plan. Of the initial $22.6 million, $14.6 million is allocated for price support and $8 million for adjustment assistance.

(iv) adjustment assistance provided to the dried vine fruit and wine grape industries. In 1986-87 the Commonwealth has appropriated $1.4 million and $5.3 million respectively for these industries, mainly as vine-pull grants with costs being shared between Commonwealth and the States on a $2: $1 basis.
(v) the National Fisheries Adjustment Scheme, which aims to restructure fisheries by reducing existing fishing capacity and under which the Government will contribute $3 million in 1986-87.

(vi) concessional funding for adjustment assistance under the Rural Adjustment Scheme. Under Part A of the Scheme, concessional loans are provided to farmers who will be viable in the longer term for purposes of farm improvement, farm build-up and debt restructuring. Commercial finance is provided to farmers through an interest subsidy provided by the Commonwealth equivalent to 50 per cent of borrowings and associated costs. The interest subsidy determined for new lending in any one year is provided for a further six years.

Commonwealth expenditure on continuing and new loans in 1986-87 is estimated at $26.9 million; $21.5 million of this figure is reserved for new lending and should facilitate new loans of around $245 million in 1986-87. In addition continuing assistance is being provided in respect of the $95.4m of loans approved for subsidy in 1985-86.

(vii) subsidisation of the Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign. The Commonwealth provides 75 per cent of the cost of compensation and matches State funding on additional special assistance measures. In 1986-87 the cost of these measures to the Commonwealth is estimated at $16 million.

Producers also benefit from special tax provisions enabling profits obtained from the compulsory disposal of animals to be offset for income tax purposes against the cost of replacement stock, giving them greater flexibility in restocking.
(viii) the provision of $6 million in 1986-87 in financial assistance to State government for soil conservation under the National Soil Conservation Program.

(ix) assistance for the better management of Australia's scarce water resources under the Federal Water Resources Assistance Program involving an allocation of about $48 million to the States in 1986-87.

(x) concessional loans for a range of disasters including bushfire, flood, drought and related occurences. The Commonwealth reimburses part of the amount to the State according to a formula under the National Disaster Relief Arrangements. After State expenditure reaches a trigger level, the Commonwealth provides a 50 per cent subsidy until a further trigger level is reached where the Commonwealth share increases to 75 per cent. Conditions vary from State to State but loans are generally made available at a low interest rate, typically for a maximum value of $30,000 to $60,000 depending upon the State, the nature of disaster and the applicant's particular circumstances. Loans are generally only made where the applicant is unable to obtain further finance from commercial sources.

(xi) matching $1 for $1 industry contributions to 14 rural industry research funds (RIRFs) which are established under the Rural Industry Research Act 1985. The Government has also revamped the RIRFs to increase their effectiveness and to ensure research funds are more efficiently used. In 1986-87 direct Commonwealth funding for these RIRFs will total $15 million.

Assistance is also provided for research through the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account (FIRTA) and the Fisheries Development Trust Account (FDTA). Over $7 million in Commonwealth contributions is available through FIRTA in 1986-87 for research and education in Australian fishing. Under FDTA $300,000 is available in 1986-87 to fund developments which because they are less commercially attractive may not otherwise be funded.

Total Commonwealth outlays on rural research in 1986-87 are estimated at $44 million, which includes research moneys for the fishing, meat and wool industries whose research funds are not covered by the Rural Industry Research Act 1985.

In addition, the Commonwealth directly funds the CSIRO and the BAE, and more recently has created the Bureau of Rural Science within the Department of Primary Industry in further recognition of the need to incorporate advanced technology in rural industries.
Primary producers will also benefit indirectly from the tax deduction of 150 per cent on private sector research and development in such areas as biotechnology and food processing.
(xii) provision of substantial funding for wool promotion, estimated at $36 million in 1986-87.
(xiii) allocation of $5 million a year for five years to an Innovative Agricultural Marketing Program to sponsor innovative projects.

(xiv) funding of research on meat markets and consumer satisfaction with meat products through the Meat Marketing Innovation Grant which the Government introduced in 1985-86, and which will provide $7 million over 4 years. Expenditure from the Grant is expected to be around $2 million in 1986-87.

(xv) reform of statutory marketing authorities to increase their flexibility and efficiency and to improve their professionalism in management, finance, marketing and promotion. Similarly the membership of industry policy councils has been revised. While such measures do not provide immediate or tangible benefits, their beneficial effects over the longer term are likely to far outweigh the direct financial outlays or subsidies enjoyed by the rural sector.

The Government has also established the Rural and Allied Industries Council consisting of industry, union and Government leaders, to research issues of concern to the rural and related sectors of the economy and provide a forum through which the members can resolve potential conflicts and work jointly toward the removal of impediments to progress in all aspects of primary production and marketing.

(xvi) the allocation of $0.5 million for feasibility studies of the scope for developing processing plants for wool, cotton and hides, together with a commitment to provide substantial funding for such projects, subject to the outcome of the feasibility studies.

(xvii) the provision of National Interest Cover for substantial rural exports (particularly grain) to countries where there is a relatively high risk of default and insurance facilities normally available through the Export Finance Insurance Corporation are not available.
Notwithstanding the assistance provided by these industry-specific measures, primary producers have perhaps benefitted most from more general developments at the macro-economic level. In particular
(i) the devaluation of the Australian dollar has boosted returns to agriculture well above the level they would otherwise have been.
(ii) deregulation of the financial system and increased competition in the banking system has ensured an adequate flow of funds to all sectors, including the rural sector.
(iii) the Government's policy of wage restraint has substantially eased inflationary pressures thus restraining cost increases and reducing real unit labour costs.
(iv) the reduction of protection in key industries-steel, chemical and plastics, motor vehicles, textiles, clothing and footwear-will enhance overall economic efficiency and reduce input costs.

The Government's approach to the rural sector is not, however, limited to assisting only primary producers. Rather, it takes a holistic approach, reflecting its concern for the well-being of the rural community generally. It is therefore concerned that rural communities are not disadvantaged in comparison with urban communities. To this end it:
(i) subsidises by 50 per cent the cost of employment of rural counsellors in areas requiring the service.

(ii) provides substantial funding under Part C of the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS). As outlined above, the RAS provides financial assistance to assist industry adjustment. Through Part C of the Scheme funds are provided to assist farmers suffering financial hardship to ``carry-on'' while they consider whether to leave farming and to assist those who have left farming. Estimated expenditure under Part C in 1986-87 is $5 million. This assistance complements unemployment benefits available to farmers who meet the eligibility requirements.

(iii) subsidises regional air services. In 1986-87, the Government has provided a rebate of 50 per cent ($2.3m) of aircraft movement charges payable by the commuter airlines to assist in the transition to the new method of charging this financial year. Also, a rebate of 15 per cent of annual Air Navigation Charges is provided to the registered owners of aerial agricultural aircraft and a further 50 per cent rebate is provided to the owners of general aviation aircraft which are not normally domiciled at Commonwealth funded aerodromes. A significant proportion of the benefits of these rebates is received by primary producers.
(iv) subsidises a number of rural services including the Royal Flying Doctor Service and education for isolated children.
(v) grants remote area allowances in social security payments and taxation zone allowances and rebates.
(vi) subsidises communications facilities to rural Australia.

(viii) provides Commonwealth assistance to the States and NT under natural disaster relief arrangements. In 1986-87 the Commonwealth contribution is expected to be well in excess of the Budget estimate of $24 million.

(2) Primary producers receive a full rebate of the excise paid on diesel fuel used off-road. This recognises that the cost of diesel fuel, as an input to production, influences the price of farm output and thus its competitiveness in world markets. Diesel is therefore available to the rural, fishing and forestry industries at world prices.
On the basis of present estimates of consumption of diesel by primary producers and the current operable rate of rebate, this assistance will save primary producers around $260 million in 1986-87.
As set out in the response to Question 1 concessional finance is made available through the RAS.
The Commonwealth also facilitates the availability of finance to the rural sector through the
Commonwealth Development Bank, which because of its operating arrangements, is able to provide loans at very competitive rates, and
the Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which provides re-financing loans to major lenders and directly lends to farmers at very competitive rates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say which Aboriginal communities or organisations receive foreign aid and which organisations provide the aid.
(2) Is he able to say how much the Aboriginal communities or organisations receive and how this money is spent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs is not in a position to check the source of all non-Commonwealth funding that an Aboriginal community or organisation may receive.
